questions.Question: Innocent III, who became pope in 1198 led
questions.solution: Solution:		Innocent III, who became pope in 1198 led the fourth crusade. The Fourth Crusade (1202-1204 CE) was called by Pope Innocent III (r. 1198-1216 CE) to retake Jerusalem from its current Muslim overlords.

questions.Question: In which year a resolution 'Uniting for Peace' was adopted by UN General Assembly?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1950 a resolution 'Uniting for Peace' was adopted by UN General Assembly. The Uniting for Peace resolution was initiated by the United States, and submitted by the "Joint Seven-Powers" in October 1950, as a means of circumventing further Soviet vetoes during the course of the Korean War (25 June 1950 – 27 July 1953). It was adopted by 52 votes to 5, with 2 abstentions.

questions.Question: In which of the following organs of human body does maximum absorption of food take place?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Small intestine of human body does maximum absorption of food take place. The small intestine or small bowel is an organ in the gastrointestinal tract where most of the end absorption of nutrients and minerals from food takes place.

questions.Question: Human Rights Day is on
questions.solution: Solution:		Human Rights Day is on 10 December. This day is celebrated internationally to honor 10th Dec 1948, when the United Nations adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights at Palais de Challoit, Paris after the experience of the Second World War.

questions.Question: In the 2002 World Cup Hockey Finals, Germany beat ____
questions.solution: Solution:		In the 2002 World Cup Hockey Finals, Germany beat Australia. The 2002 Men's Hockey World Cup was the 10th edition of the Hockey World Cup, a men's field hockey tournament. It was held from 24 February to 9 March 2002 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Germany won their first title after defeating Australia 2–1 in the final.

questions.Question: Thomas Cup is associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		Thomas Cup is associated with badminton. The Thomas Cup, sometimes called the World Men's Team Championships, is an international badminton competition among teams representing member nations of the Badminton World Federation (BWF), the sport's global governing body.

questions.Question: Theory of Idealism was expounded by George Hegal, Bishop George and Berkeley According to this
questions.optionA: mathli is an illusion and that the only reality that which exists mentally
questions.optionB: good was pleasure and that evil was pain
questions.optionC: base of knowledge is sense-experience, that is, observations governed by scientific principles
questions.optionD: all knowledge is derived from sensory experience, by observing and experimenting
questions.solution: Solution:		Theory of Idealism was expounded by George Hegal, Bishop George and Berkeley According to this mathli is an illusion and that the only reality that which exists mentally. Idealism is the group of metaphysical philosophies which assert that reality, or reality as humans can know it, is fundamentally mental, mentally constructed, or otherwise immaterial.

questions.Question: Vitamin B12 is most useful for combating
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin B12 is most useful for combating anemia. Having vitamin B12 deficiency means that your body does not have enough of this vitamin. You need B12 to make red blood cells, which carry oxygen through your body. Not having enough B12 can lead to anemia, which means your body does not have enough red blood cells to do the job. This can make you feel weak and tired. Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause damage to your nerves and can affect memory and thinking.

questions.Question: To prevent loss of weight plants reduce transpiration by
questions.solution: Solution:		To prevent loss of weight plants reduce transpiration by shedding of leaves, reducing the size of leaves and developing hair around stomata.

questions.Question: The term which denotes that each side has made equal point at game point, in Tennis, is referred to as
questions.solution: Solution:		The term which denotes that each side has made equal point at game point, in Tennis, is referred to as deuce. Deuce is the score in a game of tennis when both players have forty points. One player has to win two points one after the other to win the game.

questions.Question: Which atomic reactor is used for studies of uranium heavy water lattice?
questions.solution: Solution:		Zerlina atomic reactor is used for studies of uranium heavy water lattice. Zerlina was used for studies of the spatial arrangement of fissionable and nonfissionable materials in uranium heavy water reactors. The tank-type reactor was the first of a series of critical assemblies built by BARC.

questions.Question: Which language is spoken in Karnataka?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kannada language is spoken in Karnataka. Kannada, one of the classical languages of India, is the most widely spoken and official language of the state. Other languages spoken include Urdu, Konkani, Marathi, Tulu, Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Kodava and Beary.

questions.Question: Which are the important minerals found in Manipur?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sillimanite, nickel, petroleum are the important minerals found in manipur.

questions.Question: When was Lord Buddha born?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Buddha was born in 560 BC. Buddha, born with the name Siddhartha Gautama, was a teacher, philosopher and spiritual leader who is considered the founder of Buddhism. He lived and taught in the region around the border of modern-day Nepal and India sometime between the 6th to 4th century B.C.

questions.Question: Which missile is designed to defend large installation like oil-fields etc. against enemy air attacks?
questions.solution: Solution:		Akash missile is designed to defend large installation like oil-fields etc. against enemy air attacks. Akash is a surface-to-air missile with an intercept range of 30 km. It has a launch weight of 720 kg, a diameter of 35 cm and a length of 5.78 metres. Akash flies at supersonic speed, reaching around Mach 2.5. It can reach an altitude of 18 km and can be fired from both tracked and wheeled platforms.

questions.Question: The headquarter of the United Nations is at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of the United Nations is at New York.The United Nations is headquartered in New York City, in a complex designed by a board of architects led by Wallace Harrison, and built by the architectural firm Harrison & Abramovitz. The complex has served as the official headquarters of the United Nations since its completion in 1952.

questions.Question: The main purpose of the Group of 77 was
questions.optionB: to promote African unity and solidarity
questions.optionC: to defend the economic and trade interests of the developing nations of the world
questions.solution: Solution:		The main purpose of the Group of 77 was to defend the economic and trade interests of the developing nations of the world. The primary goals of the G-77 are to maintain the independence and sovereignty of all developing countries, to defend the economic interests of member countries by insisting on equal standing with developed countries in the global marketplace, to establish a united front on issues of common concern, and to strengthen ties between member countries. Because of the historical significance of the meeting, the name G-77 has been kept despite the group’s growth to include more than 130 countries.

questions.Question: The largest party of Ireland, the Ulster Unionist Party, endorses the Northern Ireland peace deal between British and Irish governments in
questions.solution: Solution:		The largest party of Ireland, the Ulster Unionist Party, endorses the Northern Ireland peace deal between British and Irish governments in 1998. The Belfast Agreement is also known as the Good Friday Agreement, because it was reached on Good Friday, 10 April 1998. It was a peace agreement between the British and Irish governments, and most of the political parties in Northern Ireland, on how Northern Ireland should be governed.

questions.Question: The last ruler of the Mughal dynasty was
questions.solution: Solution:		The last ruler of the Mughal dynasty was Bahadurshah Zafar. The last Mughal emperor, Bahadur Shah II, also known as Zafar, died in a British prison in Burma in 1862. As the last of the dynastic line that extended back to the sixteenth century, he had in his earlier years presided over a culturally sophisticated court, but as the British East India Company extended its control over more of India, his rule was clearly coming to an end.

questions.Question: The headquarter of the Warsaw Treaty Organization were at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of the Warsaw Treaty Organization were at Moscow. It was founded after the admission of West Germany to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the equivalent organization of Western Europe. Its headquarters were in Moscow, and it was effectively controlled by the Soviet Union.

questions.Question: Satyajit Ray received Magsaysay Award for journalism, literature and creative communication arts in
questions.solution: Solution:		Satyajit Ray received Magsaysay Award for journalism, literature and creative communication arts in 1967. The Ramon Magsaysay Award, Asia's premier prize and highest honor, celebrates greatness of spirit and transformative leadership in Asia.

questions.Question: The agreement according to which the UK, the USA and the former USSR cannot assist other countries in acquiring technology to develop nuclear weapons, is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The agreement according to which the UK, the USA and the former USSR cannot assist other countries in acquiring technology to develop nuclear weapons, is known as Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty (NPT). The NPT non-nuclear-weapon states agree never to acquire nuclear weapons and the NPT nuclear-weapon states in exchange agree to share the benefits of peaceful nuclear technology and to pursue nuclear disarmament aimed at the ultimate elimination of their nuclear arsenals.

questions.Question: The 'Red Triangle' symbol denotes
questions.solution: Solution:		The 'Red Triangle' symbol denotes family planning. An inverted Red Triangle is the symbol for family planning health and contraception services, much as the red cross is a symbol for medical services.

questions.Question: P.T. Usha, who came close to bagging a bronze finished fourth in  ____ in 1984 Olympics.
questions.solution: Solution:		P.T. Usha, who came close to bagging a bronze finished fourth in 400 m hurdle in 1984 Olympics. Pilavullakandi Thekkeparambil Usha is a retired Indian track and field athlete. She has been associated with Indian athletics since 1979. She is often called the "queen of Indian track and field".

questions.Question: Photophobia is
questions.optionC: the adjustment of the eye for light
questions.optionD: a disease cause by too much sunlight
questions.solution: Solution:		Photophobia is abnormal intolerance of light. Photophobia is a symptom of abnormal intolerance to visual perception of light. As a medical symptom, photophobia is not a morbid fear or phobia, but an experience of discomfort or pain to the eyes due to light exposure or by presence of actual physical sensitivity of the eyes, though the term is sometimes additionally applied to abnormal or irrational fear of light such as heliophobia.

questions.Question: For the Olympics and World Tournaments, the dimensions of basketball court are
questions.solution: Solution:		For the Olympics and World Tournaments, the dimensions of basketball court are 28 m x 15 m.

questions.Question: Federation Cup, World Cup, Allywyn International Trophy and Challenge Cup are awarded to winners of
questions.solution: Solution:		Federation Cup, World Cup, Allywyn International Trophy and Challenge Cup are awarded to winners of Volleyball.

questions.Question: Each year World Red Cross and Red Crescent Day is celebrated on
questions.solution: Solution:		Each year World Red Cross and Red Crescent Day is celebrated on May 8. This date is the anniversary of the birth of Henry Dunant, who was born on 8 May 1828.

questions.Question: Famous sculptures depicting art of love built some time in 950 AD - 1050 AD are
questions.solution: Solution:		Famous sculptures depicting art of love built some time in 950 AD - 1050 AD are Khajuraho temples. The Khajuraho Group of Monuments is a group of Hindu temples and Jain temples in Chhatarpur district, Madhya Pradesh, India, about 175 kilometres southeast of Jhansi. They are a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The temples are famous for their nagara-style architectural symbolism and their erotic sculptures.

questions.Question: Gravity setting chambers are used in industries to remove
questions.solution: Solution:		Gravity setting chambers are used in industries to remove suspended particulate matter. A Gravitational Settling Chamber is a rectangular chamber in which several horizontal trays are fixed. When the polluted gas enters the chamber, its velocity is kept low so that the particulates get sufficient time to settle down due to gravity.

questions.Question: The first lady Prime Minister of a country was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first lady Prime Minister of a country was Srimavo Bhadaranaike (Sri Lanka). Ratwatte Dias Bandaranaike, also called Sirimavo R.D. Bandaranaike, (born April 17, 1916, Ratnapura, Ceylon [now Sri Lanka]—died October 10, 2000, Colombo, Sri Lanka), stateswoman who, upon her party’s victory in the 1960 general election in Ceylon (later Sri Lanka), became the world’s first woman prime minister.

questions.Question: The common pesticides which are in use consist of
questions.solution: Solution:		The common pesticides which are in use consist of olefins. Olefin, also called alkene, compound made up of hydrogen and carbon that contains one or more pairs of carbon atoms linked by a double bond. Olefins are examples of unsaturated hydrocarbons (compounds that contain only hydrogen and carbon and at least one double or triple bond).

questions.Question: The dance in Himachal Pradesh, performed indoor, solo or duet, especially when life comes to a standstill during cold winter is
questions.solution: Solution:		The dance in Himachal Pradesh, performed indoor, solo or duet, especially when life comes to a standstill during cold winter is Munzra. The Himachal is known to be the Dev Bhoomi.There are various traditional dance forms of Himachal Pradesh for each and every occasion.

questions.Question: The battle tanks that have been modernized to keep pace with the latest technology development is
questions.solution: Solution:		The battle tanks that have been modernized to keep pace with the latest technology development is Vijayanta. The Vijayanta (en: "Victorious") was a main battle tank built in India based on a licensed design of the Vickers Mk. The Vijayanta was the first indigenous tank of the Indian Army. The prototype was completed in 1963 and the tank entered service on December 29, 1965.

questions.Question: The first Asian Games were held in 1951 at
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Asian Games were held in 1951 at New Delhi, India. India participated and hosted the 1951 Asian Games held in the capital city , New Delhi from 4 to 11 March 1951. India was ranked second with 15 gold medals in this edition of the Asiad. Sachin Nag won a gold in swimming in this edition.

questions.Question: The headquarter of ECA (Economic Commission for Africa) are situated at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of ECA (Economic Commission for Africa) are situated at Addis Ababa. Addis Ababa, also spelled Addis Abeba, capital and largest city of Ethiopia. It is located on a well-watered plateau surrounded by hills and mountains, in the geographic centre of the country.

questions.Question: The last month of the Saka year is
questions.solution: Solution:		The last month of the Saka year is Phalguna. Phagun is the twelfth and last month of the Nanakshahi calendar, which governs activities within Sikhism. This month coincides with Phalguna in the Hindu calendar and the Indian National calendar, and February and March of the Gregorian and Julian calendars and is 30 or 31 days long.

questions.Question: The Olympic Flame, was, for the first time, ceremonially lighted and burnt in a giant torch at the entrance of the stadium at
questions.solution: Solution:		The Olympic Flame, was, for the first time, ceremonially lighted and burnt in a giant torch at the entrance of the stadium at Amsterdam Games (1928). An employee of the Electric Utility of Amsterdam lit the first modern Olympic flame in the Marathon Tower of the Olympic Stadium in Amsterdam. The Olympic flame has been part of the Summer Olympics ever since.

questions.Question: The Olympic Flame symbolises
questions.optionA: unity among various nations of the world
questions.optionC: sports as a means for securing harmony among nations
questions.optionD: continuity between the ancient and modern games
questions.solution: Solution:		The Olympic Flame symbolises continuity between the ancient and modern games. On the opening day of the Games, the torch is taken into the stadium and the chosen torchbearer lights the cauldron. This ritual symbolizes the continuity between ancient times and the new generations. The Flame burns for the entire duration of the Games and is extinguished during the Closing Ceremony of the competition.

questions.Question: The reaction which converts sugar solution into alcohol is an example of
questions.solution: Solution:		The reaction which converts sugar solution into alcohol is an example of fermentation. Fermentation is a metabolic process in which an organism converts a carbohydrate, such as starch or a sugar, into an alcohol or an acid.

questions.Question: The first meeting of the UN General Assembly was held in which of the following cities?
questions.solution: Solution:		The first session of the UN General Assembly was convened on 10 January 1946 in the Methodist Central Hall in London and included representatives of 51 nations.

questions.Question: The first rice straw power plant has been set up at
questions.solution: Solution:		The first rice straw power plant has been set up at Jalkheri, Punjab. The Jalkheri Power Plant becomes operational, not only about 80,000 MT per annum of rice straw shall be consumed for producing electricity, but this will also save environment from getting polluted which otherwise is polluted due to burning of rice straw by farmers.

questions.Question: The founder member of EFTA are
questions.solution: Solution:		The founder member of EFTA are Austria, Denmark, Norway, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland, UK, Austria, Sweden. During the 1960s, these countries were often referred to as the "Outer Seven", as opposed to the Inner Six of the then European Economic Community (EEC).

questions.Question: The first historical mention of the holding of the ancient Olympic Games occurred about
questions.solution: Solution:		The first historical mention of the holding of the ancient Olympic Games occurred about 2775 years ago.

questions.Question: The first Afro-Asian Games were held in
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Afro-Asian Games were held between October 24, 2003 and November 1, 2003 in Hyderabad, India.

questions.Question: Liquid asset is
questions.optionA: a type of asset that is in cash in the current account of the commercial bank
questions.optionB: a type of asset that is in the form of a deposit in the current account of the commercial bank
questions.solution: Solution:		Liquid asset is a type of asset either that is in cash in the current account of the commercial bank or a type of asset that is in the form of a deposit in the current account of the commercial bank.

questions.Question: Jeevan Rekha (Life line) express is
questions.optionA: first hospital on wheels in the world
questions.solution: Solution:		Jeevan Rekha (Life line) express is first hospital on wheels in the world. The Lifeline Express or Jeevan Rekha Express is World’s first hospital train run by the Impact India Foundation. It was developed in collaboration with the Indian Railways and Health Ministry and has been funded by Impact UK, international charitable sources, Indian corporate houses and individuals. Here are 10 things to know about the lifeline express.

questions.Question: Lata Mangeshkar holds the world record for maximum number of ____
questions.solution: Solution:		Lata Mangeshkar holds the world record for maximum number of song recordings. Lata Mangeshkar sang over 700 songs for the composer duo over a period of 35 long years, most of which became huge hits.

questions.Question: On August 1, 2003, the total strength of India's armed forces approximate to
questions.solution: Solution:		On August 1, 2003, the total strength of India's armed forces approximate to 13,92,000.

questions.Question: John F. Kennedy was
questions.optionA: one the most popular Presidents of USA
questions.optionC: writer of Why England slept and Profile in Courage
questions.solution: Solution:		John F. Kennedy was one the most popular Presidents of USA, the first Roman Catholic President and the writer of Why England slept and Profile in Courage.

questions.Question: The best way to tackle local environmental problems is to
questions.optionC: leave it to the local public to decide
questions.optionD: provide environmental education to the local people and create awareness
questions.solution: Solution:		The best way to tackle local environmental problems is to provide environmental education to the local people and create awareness. Environmental protection is the process of protecting the environment for the benefit of nature and humans.

questions.Question: The first attempt in printing was made in England by
questions.solution: Solution:		The first attempt in printing was made in England by William Caxton. William Caxton was an English merchant, diplomat, and writer. He is thought to be the first person to introduce a printing press into England, in 1476, and as a printer was the first English retailer of printed books.

questions.Question: The first foreigner to receive Bharat Ratna was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first foreigner to receive Bharat Ratna was Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan. Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan also known as frontier Gandhi from the Pakistan was the first foreigner to bestowed with Bharat ratna. he played active role during the freedom struggle of India most notably during the formation of Khudai khidmatgar(servants of god) movement. He was one of the close friend of Mahatama Gandhi.

questions.Question: The first General Elections in India took place in
questions.solution: Solution:		The first General Elections in India took place in 1952. General elections to the first Lok Sabha since independence were held in India between 25 October 1951 and 21 February 1952. The Indian National Congress (INC) stormed into power, winning 364 of the 489 seats. Jawaharlal Nehru became the first democratically elected Prime Minister of the country.

questions.Question: The corresponding Gregorian date of the saka month, Bhadra is
questions.solution: Solution:		The corresponding Gregorian date of the saka month, Bhadra is August 23.

questions.Question: Mother Teresa received the Magsaysay Award in 1962 in the area of
questions.solution: Solution:		Mother Teresa received the Magsaysay Award in 1962 in the area of international understanding. Teresa received the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Peace and International Understanding, given for work in South or East Asia, in 1962. According to its citation, "The Board of Trustees recognises her merciful cognisance of the abject poor of a foreign land, in whose service she has led a new congregation".

questions.Question: Of the various non-conventional energy sources that are being tapped, which has the largest potential?
questions.solution: Solution:		Of the various non-conventional energy sources that are being tapped, Solar power has the largest potential. There is a capacity of about 1, 95,000 MW non-conventional energy in India. 31 % of it is the form of solar energy, 30% in ocean and geo-thermal, 26 % in biomass and 10 % in wind energy. India is a tropical country. It has enormous possibilities of tapping solar energy.

questions.Question: Missile 'prithivi' aims
questions.optionA: to test the performance of an indigenously built heat-shield
questions.optionB: to hit  target without the help of the Air Forces
questions.optionC: to defend a large installations like oil-fields etc. against enemy attacks
questions.solution: Solution:		Missile 'prithivi' aims to hit target without the help of the Air Forces. Prithvi I was one of the first missiles developed under Government of India's IGMDP. Launched in February 1988, Prithvi I is a single-stage, liquid-fuelled missile. A surface-to-surface missile, it has a range of 150 km and a mounting capability of 1000 kg. It was inducted into the Indian Army in 1994.

questions.Question: Microphone is used to convert
questions.solution: Solution:		Microphone is used to convert sound waves into electrical energy. Microphones are a type of transducer - a device which converts energy from one form to another. Microphones convert acoustical energy (sound waves) into electrical energy (the audio signal). Different types of microphone have different ways of converting energy but they all share one thing in common: The diaphragm.

questions.Question: Mount Everest is in -
questions.solution: Solution:		Mount Everest is in Nepal. Mount Everest is Earth's highest mountain above sea level, located in the Mahalangur Himal sub-range of the Himalayas. The international border between Nepal and China runs across its summit point.

questions.Question: The first man-made satellite, Sputnik I was launched by the former USSR in
questions.solution: Solution:		The first man-made satellite, Sputnik I was launched by the former USSR in 1957. The world's first artificial satellite was about the size of a beach ball (58 cm.or 22.8 inches in diameter), weighed only 83.6 kg. or 183.9 pounds, and took about 98 minutes to orbit the Earth on its elliptical path.

questions.Question: The General Assembly meets every year in regular sessions which begin on
questions.optionA: first Monday in March every year
questions.optionB: fourth Monday in September every year
questions.optionC: third Tuesday in September every year
questions.optionD: Second Tuesday in March every year
questions.solution: Solution:		The General Assembly meets every year in regular sessions which begin on third Tuesday in September every year. Tuesday of the third week in September, counting from the first week that contains at least one working day.

questions.Question: The chief of the Army staff is assisted by
questions.optionB: Principal staff officers such as Deputy Chief, Adjutant General, Military Secretary
questions.solution: Solution:		The chief of the Army staff is assisted by Vice-chief of the Army Staff and Principal staff officers such as Deputy Chief, Adjutant General, Military Secretary.

questions.Question: The dance performed by women to invoke rain in Bihar is
questions.solution: Solution:		The dance performed by women to invoke rain in Bihar is Jata Jatin. Jat Jatin is the dance of women of the Mithila region of Bihar and is supposed to be performed on moonlit nights during the monsoons. Grown-up girls and young housewives assemble in the courtyard and, accompanied by a drum, dance from midnight to dawn. As they dance, they enact in gestures the epic story of the love of Jata and Jatin. The most dramatic episode of the dance concerns a wicked boatman who breaks through the dancing ring and kidnaps the beautiful Jatin.

questions.Question: The department of Atomic Energy was established in
questions.solution: Solution:		The department of Atomic Energy was established in 1956. The Atomic Energy Commission is the governing body of the Department of Atomic Energy (DAE), Government of India. The DAE is under the direct charge of the Prime Minister. The Indian Atomic Energy Commission was set up on 10 August 1948 under the late Department of Scientific Research. A resolution passed by the Government of India later replaced the commission by "Atomic Energy Commission of India" on 1 March 1958 under the Department of Atomic Energy with more financial and executive powers.

questions.Question: The award instituted to honor outstanding agricultural scientists is
questions.solution: Solution:		The award instituted to honor outstanding agricultural scientists is Borlaug Award. The Borlaug Award is an award recognition conferred by a fertilizer company, Coromandel International, for outstanding Indian scientists for their research and contributions in the field of agriculture and environment. The award was created in 1972 and named in honour of Nobel Laureate Norman E.

questions.Question: The battle tanks designed and developed by the Defence Research and Development Organization in collaboration with Heavy Vehicles Factory and Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited are
questions.solution: Solution:		The battle tanks designed and developed by the Defence Research and Development Organization in collaboration with Heavy Vehicles Factory and Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited are Arjun.

questions.Question: The chief administrative office of the UNO, which co-ordinates and supervises the activities of the UNO, is
questions.solution: Solution:		The chief administrative office of the UNO, which co-ordinates and supervises the activities of the UNO, is the secretariat. The secretary-general, the principal administrative officer of the United Nations, is elected for a five-year renewable term by a two-thirds vote of the General Assembly and by the recommendation of the Security Council and the approval of its permanent members.

questions.Question: The first women to climb Mt. Everest was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first women to climb Mt. Everest was Junko Taibei. Junko Tabei was the first woman to reach the summit of Everest on May 16, 1975, at the age of 35. In 1975, she defied Japanese societal norms again when she left her young daughter with her husband while she traveled to Nepal to lead a group climbing Everest.

questions.Question: The five intertwined rings or circles on the Olympic Flag made of white silk are
questions.optionA: from right to left blue, yellow, black, green and red respectively
questions.optionB: from left to right blue, yellow, black, green and red respectively
questions.optionC: from right to left blue, black, green, red and yellow respectively
questions.optionD: from left to right yellow, red, green, black and blue respectively
questions.solution: Solution:		The five intertwined rings or circles on the Olympic Flag made of white silk are from left to right blue, yellow, black, green and red respectively.

questions.Question: Radioactive substances can be produced readily in
questions.solution: Solution:		Radioactive substances can be produced readily in an atomic pile. Radioactive substances are atoms that decay naturally. They can give off alpha particles, beta particles and gamma radiation. Unlike X-ray sources they cannot be turned off, so their control is more difficult.

questions.Question: The 2002 Commonwealth Games were held in
questions.solution: Solution:		The 2002 Commonwealth Games were held in UK. The 2002 Commonwealth Games, officially known as the XVII Commonwealth Games and commonly known as Manchester 2002 were held in Manchester, England, from 25 July to 4 August 2002.

questions.Question: Profit made when an asset is sold more than the price at which it was bought is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Profit made when an asset is sold more than the price at which it was bought is called capital-gain. Capital gain is the profit one earns on the sale of an asset like stocks, bonds or real estate. It results in capital gain when the selling price of an asset exceeds its purchase price. It is the difference between the selling price (higher) and cost price (lower) of the asset.

questions.Question: Plorence(Chadwick) is the associated place for which of the following sport?
questions.solution: Solution:		Plorence(Chadwick) is the associated place for Skiing.

questions.Question: The 2012 Olympics Games were held in
questions.solution: Solution:		The 2012 Olympics Games were held in London. The 2012 Summer Olympics, formally the Games of the XXX Olympiad and commonly known as London 2012, was an international multi-sport event that was held from 27 July to 12 August 2012 in London, United Kingdom.

questions.Question: The Territorial Army was established in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Territorial Army was established in 1948. It was replaced by the Auxiliary Force (for Europeans and Eurasians) and the Indian Territorial Force (for Indians) in 1920. The modern Territorial Army was inaugurated by the first Indian Governor-General of India, C. Rajagopalachari, on 9 October 1949 after the Independence Territorial Army Act was passed in 1948.

questions.Question: Tiger Woods is associated with which of the following sports?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tiger Woods is associated with Golf. Eldrick Tont "Tiger" Woods (born December 30, 1975) is an American professional golfer. He is tied for first in PGA Tour wins and ranks second in men's major championships and also holds numerous golf records. Woods is widely regarded as one of the greatest golfers, and one of the most famous athletes of all time.

questions.Question: The UN charter was ratified in 1945 by
questions.solution: Solution:		The UN charter was ratified in 1945 by 29 nations.

questions.Question: Uttaranchal has international boundary with ____  in north, north-east and eastern side.
questions.solution: Solution:		Uttaranchal has international boundary with China and Nepalin north, north-east and eastern side.

questions.Question: The trophy know by the name of Grand Prix is associated with
questions.optionD: table tennis, lawn tennis and shooting
questions.solution: Solution:		The trophy know by the name of Grand Prix is associated with table tennis, lawn tennis and shooting.

questions.Question: What is the population density of Nagaland?
questions.solution: Solution:		The population density of Nagaland is 120/sq. km. Density of Nagaland is 119 per sq km which is lower than national average 382 per sq km. In 2001, density of Nagaland was 120 per sq km, while nation average in 2001 was 324 per sq km.

questions.Question: When is Lal Bahadur Shastri's death anniversary?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lal Bahadur Shastri's death anniversary is on January, 11. Shastri died of a heart attack in Tashkent, Uzbekistan (then Soviet Union) on the 11th January, 1966, one day after signing a peace treaty to end the 1965 Indo-Pakistan War.

questions.Question: When and where was basketball introduced in Olympics as a medal event?
questions.solution: Solution:		Basketball at the 1936 Summer Olympics was the first appearance of the sport of basketball as an official Olympic medal event. The tournament was played between 7 August and 14 August 1936 in Berlin, Germany.

questions.Question: When did first test tube baby - Louise Brown born?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1978 first test tube baby - Louise Brown was born. Louise Joy Brown is best known as the world's first "test-tube baby." Her birth by Caesarian section shortly before midnight on July 25, 1978, at Oldham General Hospital in England, made headlines around the world.

questions.Question: What is the density of population in Chandigarh?
questions.solution: Solution:		The density of population in Chandigarh is 7,902/sq. km.

questions.Question: Which industries are common in Andhra Pradesh?
questions.optionB: Asbestos and units of HMT, BHEL
questions.optionC: Hindustan Shipyard and Bharat Dynamics Limited
questions.solution: Solution:		Cement and paper, Asbestos and units of HMT, BHEL and Hindustan Shipyard and Bharat Dynamics Limited industries are common in Andhra Pradesh.

questions.Question: Which of the following act as a channel of transmission of blood to the heart in the human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Veins act as a channel of transmission of blood to the heart in the human body. Blood enters the heart through two large veins, the inferior and superior vena cava, emptying oxygen-poor blood from the body into the right atrium of the heart. As the atrium contracts, blood flows from your right atrium into your right ventricle through the open tricuspid valve.

questions.Question: Which of the following are the members of OPEC (Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries)?
questions.solution: Solution:		Algeria, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, United Arab Emirates, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela are the members of OPEC (Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries).

questions.Question: Which of the following acts as a resistance against in the body?
questions.solution: Solution:		White corpuscles acts as a resistance against in the body. White blood cells (also called leukocytes or immune cells) are cells which form a component of the blood. They help to defend the body against infectious disease and foreign materials as part of the immune system.

questions.Question: Which of the following chemicals is useful in photography?
questions.solution: Solution:		Silver bromide is useful in photography. When silver bromide is exposed to light it undergoes photochemical decomposition. The silver ions present in silver bromide are reduced to silver metal which remains as an opaque image on the photographic film.

questions.Question: The main purpose of ASEAN (Association of South-East Asian Nations) is
questions.optionA: to provide collective defence and economic cooperation
questions.optionB: to maintain higher standards of living among member nations
questions.optionC: to accelerate economic progress and maintain economic stability
questions.solution: Solution:		The main purpose of ASEAN (Association of South-East Asian Nations) is to accelerate economic progress and maintain economic stability. Its principal aims include accelerating economic growth, social progress, and sociocultural evolution among its members, alongside the protection of regional stability and the provision of a mechanism for member countries to resolve differences peacefully.

questions.Question: The main object of which of the following UN agency is to help the underdeveloped countries in the task of raising their living standards?
questions.solution: Solution:		IMF - International Monetary Fund UNICEF - United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund UNDP - United Nations Development Programme IDA - International Development Association

questions.Question: The headquarter of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are at Vienna. Since 1965, the headquarters of OPEC has been in Vienna, Austria. OPEC was established in Baghdad, Iraq on 10–14 September 1960.

questions.Question: The language spoken in Lakshadweep island is
questions.solution: Solution:		The language spoken in Lakshadweep island is Malayalam. The principal languages of Lakshadweep are Malayalam, Jeseri (Dweep Bhasha) and Mahl. The people of all the northern islands speak a dialect of Malayalam with the influence of Tamil and Arabic similar to Arwi.

questions.Question: The life history of human malaria parasite in Anopheles was first described by
questions.solution: Solution:		The life history of human malaria parasite in Anopheles was first described by Ronald Ross. On 20 August 1897, in Secunderabad, Ross made his landmark discovery. While dissecting the stomach tissue of an anopheline mosquito fed four days previously on a malarious patient, he found the malaria parasite and went on to prove the role of Anopheles mosquitoes in the transmission of malaria parasites in humans.

questions.Question: Which of the following are the native languages of Manipur?
questions.solution: Solution:		Manipuri and English are the native languages of Manipur. Before Manipur got independence and merged into the Indian Union this language has been used as official language. Manipuri is the medium of instruction in all levels of education while English is another language, which is also used in the courts, offices etc.

questions.Question: Where did the three leaders, F.D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin, meet in 1943 and agreed on the need for maintaining international peace?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Teheran the three leaders, F.D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin, meet in 1943 and agreed on the need for maintaining international peace. The Tehran Conference (codenamed Eureka) was a strategy meeting of Joseph Stalin, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Winston Churchill from 28 November to 1 December 1943, after the Anglo-Soviet Invasion of Iran.

questions.Question: Where was the headquarters of European Union located?
questions.solution: Solution:		Brussels was the headquarters of European Union located. Brussels in Belgium is considered the de facto capital of the European Union, having a long history of hosting the institutions of the European Union within its European Quarter.

questions.Question: When was the city Rome found by Ramulus?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to legend, ancient Rome was founded by the two brothers, and demigods, Romulus and Remus, on 21 April 753 BCE. The legend claims that in an argument over who would rule the city (or, in another version, where the city would be located) Romulus killed Remus and named the city after himself.

questions.Question: Which launch vehicle is capable of placing around 1540 kg of INSAT class of satellites in geosynchronous transfer orbit of earth?
questions.solution: Solution:		GSLV launch vehicle is capable of placing around 1540 kg of INSAT class of satellites in geosynch-ronous transfer orbit of earth.

questions.Question: Dr. Linus Carl Pauling is the only person to have won two Nobel prizes individually for
questions.solution: Solution:		Dr. Linus Carl Pauling is the only person to have won two Nobel prizes individually for Chemistry in 1954, Peace Prize in 1962. He is one of four individuals to have won more than one Nobel Prize (the others being Marie Curie, John Bardeen and Frederick Sanger).

questions.Question: Free market is
questions.optionA: a condition in the international market where nations do not impose customs duty or other taxes on import of goods
questions.optionB: market where the price of a commodity is determined by free play of the forces of supply and demand
questions.optionC: ports that are exempted from payment of customs duty on articles of commerce, primarily to encourage tourism
questions.solution: Solution:		Free market is market where the price of a commodity is determined by free play of the forces of supply and demand. The free market is an economic system based on supply and demand with little or no government control. It is a summary description of all voluntary exchanges that take place in a given economic environment.

questions.Question: East Timor, which became the 191st member of the UN, is in the continent of
questions.solution: Solution:		East Timor, which became the 191st member of the UN, is in the continent of Asia. East Timor became the first new sovereign state of the 21st century on 20 May 2002 and joined the United Nations and the Community of Portuguese Language Countries.

questions.Question: Free surface of a liquid behaves like a sheet and tends to contract to the smallest possible area due to the
questions.solution: Solution:		Free surface of a liquid behaves like a sheet and tends to contract to the smallest possible area due to the force of cohesion. The force of cohesion is defined as the force of attraction between molecules of the same substance.

questions.Question: Gopal Krishna Gokhale
questions.optionA: founded the servants of India Society
questions.optionB: served as President of the Indian National Congress in 1907
questions.optionC: started as a maths teacher and rose to the position of the principal of Ferguson College, Pune
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopal Krishna Gokhale founded the servants of India Society, served as President of the Indian National Congress in 1907 and started as a maths teacher and rose to the position of the principal of Ferguson College, Pune. Gopal Krishna Gokhale, social reformer who founded a sectarian organization to work for relief of the underprivileged of India.

questions.Question: Value Added Tax (VAT) is
questions.optionA: indirect tax levied at each stage of production and distribution, from the primary produce to the re
questions.optionB: tax calculated on the selling price, but in declaring the liability to the government, the seller is
questions.solution: Solution:		A value-added tax (VAT) is a consumption tax placed on a product whenever value is added at each stage of the supply chain, from production to the point of sale. The amount of VAT that the user pays is on the cost of the product, less any of the costs of materials used in the product that have already been taxed.

questions.Question: Tripura is surrounded by ____ in the east
questions.solution: Solution:		Tripura is surrounded by Assam and Mizoram in the east. Tripura is a state in North-East India which borders Bangladesh, Mizoram and Assam. It is surrounded by Bangladesh on its north, south and west: the length of its international border is 856 km (84 per cent of its total border). It shares a 53 km long border with Assam and a 109 km long border with Mizoram.

questions.Question: The trophy given for exemplary conduct displayed by an athlete during the Olympic games is
questions.solution: Solution:		The trophy given for exemplary conduct displayed by an athlete during the Olympic games is Tokyo Trophy.

questions.Question: Toxin is a poisonous substance produce by
questions.solution: Solution:		Toxin is a poisonous substance produce by some higher plants, certain animals and pathogenic bacteria.

questions.Question: Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary at Tamil Nadu has reserves of
questions.optionD: elephant, deer, wild boar, crocodile, crangetic dolphin
questions.solution: Solution:		Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary at Tamil Nadu has reserves of important bird sanctuary. Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary is a 30-hectare (74-acre) protected area located in the Chengalpattu District and Madurantakam taluk of the state of Tamil Nadu, India. The sanctuary is about 75 kilometres (47 mi) from Chennai on National Highway 45 ([NH45]). Easily reachable from Madurantakam and Chengalpattu. More than 40,000 birds (including 26 rare species), from various parts of the world visit the sanctuary during the migratory season every year.

questions.Question: Republican party is
questions.optionA: One of the important parties in USA
questions.optionB: the political parties which has no definite principles
questions.optionC: the political party which changes with the change in the times and circumstances in the country
questions.solution: Solution:		Republican party is One of the important parties in USA, the political parties which has no definite principles and is the political party which changes with the change in the times and circumstances in the country.

questions.Question: Study of life in outer space is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Study of life in outer space is known as exobiology. This branch of science deals with nature of possible life forms on other planets. It is understanding evolution, distribution, origin, and future of life beyond our Earth. There are a lot of ongoing researches going on about the potential of other life forms in the outer space.

questions.Question: School of Aviation Medicine (Air Force) is located at
questions.solution: Solution:		School of Aviation Medicine (Air Force) is located at Bangalore.

questions.Question: Recession is
questions.optionA: slowing down of economic activity over a limited period
questions.optionB: period that results from accumulation of unsold goods, owing to fall in demand
questions.optionC: period during which unemployment may rise and demand and output may fall, leading to slump in trade
questions.solution: Solution:		Recession is slowing down of economic activity over a limited period, period that results from accumulation of unsold goods, owing to fall in demand and period during which unemployment may rise and demand and output may fall, leading to slump in trade.

questions.Question: Sir Thomas Fearnley Cup is awarded to
questions.optionA: amateur athlete, not necessarily an Olympian
questions.optionB: National Olympic Committee for outstanding work
questions.optionC: a club or a local sport association for remarkable achievements
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Thomas Fearnley Cup is awarded to a club or a local sport association for remarkable achievements. Fearnley became Honorary Member of the IOC 1951. In 1950, he founded the Fearnley Cup to honor an amateur sport club or a local amateur sport association based upon meritorious achievement in the service of the Olympic Movement. He originated the Fearnley Olympic Award in connection with the 1952 Winter Olympics in Oslo. The award is given for outstanding achievements by a Norwegian Olympic participant.

questions.Question: Which amongst the following has the lowest metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (mm3/g hour)?
questions.solution: Solution:		Elephant has the lowest metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (mm3/g hour).

questions.Question: Which of the following causes Poliomyelitis?
questions.solution: Solution:		Enterovirus causes Poliomyelitis. Poliomyelitis is an acute communicable disease of humans caused by a human enterovirus of the Picornaviridae family. The virus is composed of a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome and a protein capsid. Most poliovirus infections cause asymptomatic viral replication that is limited to the alimentary tract.

questions.Question: Where is the BARC's Research Centre?
questions.solution: Solution:		Variable Energy Cyclotron Centre, Kolkata,Nuclear Research Lab, Kashmir and High Altitude Research Lab, Gulmarg is the BARC's Research Centre.

questions.Question: Zawar (Rajasthan) is famous for
questions.solution: Solution:		Zawar (Rajasthan) is famous for zinc mines. Zawar is a township created by mining company Hindustan Zinc Limited, for extraction of zinc and lead. An 80MW power plant provides electricity for mining zinc and lead from three major mines.

questions.Question: Which of the following cities will be the host of XIX Commonwealth Games 2010?
questions.solution: Solution:		Delhi will be the host of XIX Commonwealth Games 2010.

questions.Question: What is the literacy rate of West Bengal?
questions.solution: Solution:		The literacy rate of West Bengal is 69.22 per cent. 77.58 of the literate population are men and 60.22 per cent women.

questions.Question: What is the circumference of table tennis ball?
questions.solution: Solution:		3.71 - 3.82 cm is the circumference of table tennis ball.

questions.Question: What is the capital of Jharkhand?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ranchi is the capital of Jharkhand. Ranchi was the centre of the Jharkhand movement, which called for a separate state for the tribal regions of South Bihar, northern Orissa, western West Bengal and the eastern area of what is present-day Chhattisgarh.

questions.Question: When did Hitler became President of Germany?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1934 Hitler became President of Germany. With the death of President Hindenburg on August 2, 1934, Hitler united the chancellorship and presidency under the new title of Fuhrer. As the economy improved, popular support for Hitler's regime became strong, and a cult of Fuhrer worship was propagated by Hitler's capable propagandists.

questions.Question: What is the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS)?
questions.optionA: Group of 53 former colonies of Britain
questions.optionB: Group of 12 former republics of dissolved USSR
questions.optionD: Group of Islamic countries in Saudi Arabia region
questions.solution: Solution:		Group of 12 former republics of dissolved USSR is the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS).

questions.Question: On a night when the sky is clear, the temperature may dip considerably; on a cloudy night the temperature will usually dip much less. The reason for this difference is that
questions.optionA: the clear sky allows radiant energy to escape readily from the earth
questions.optionB: on a cloudy night the clouds are warm and therefore retard the cooling
questions.optionC: the clear sky allows the cold of outer space to reach the earth
questions.optionD: current of air carry the heat away from the earth on a clear night
questions.solution: Solution:		On a night when the sky is clear, the temperature may dip considerably; on a cloudy night the temperature will usually dip much less. The reason for this difference is that the clear sky allows radiant energy to escape readily from the earth.

questions.Question: Normally the Commonwealth Games are held at intervals of
questions.solution: Solution:		Normally the Commonwealth Games are held at intervals of 4 years. The Commonwealth Games is an international multi-sport event involving athletes from the Commonwealth of Nations. The event was first held in 1930, and has taken place every four years since then.

questions.Question: Mahakavi Kalidas
questions.optionA: was one of the greatest Sanskrit poet and dramatist
questions.optionB: lived during the reign of Chandragupta Vikaramaditya
questions.optionC: famous works include Shakuntala, Raghuvansha, Meghdoot and Kumara Sambahava
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahakavi Kalidas was one of the greatest Sanskrit poet and dramatist, lived during the region of Chandragupta Vikaramaditya and famous works include Shakutala, Raghuvansha, Meghdoot and Kumara Sambahava.

questions.Question: Olympic emblem is composed of five intertwined rings, each of a different colour, representing the five continents of the world as
questions.optionA: Blue ring - Europe; Yellow ring - Asia; Black ring - Africa; Red ring- America; Green ring - Oceania
questions.optionB: Blue ring - Asia; Yellow ring - Europe; Black ring - Oceania; Red ring- Africa; Green ring - America
questions.optionC: Blue ring - Europe; Yellow ring - Asia; Black ring - Africa; Red ring- Oceania; Green ring - America
questions.optionD: Blue ring - Asia; Yellow ring - Europe; Black ring - Africa; Red ring- America; Green ring - Oceania
questions.solution: Solution:		Olympic emblem is composed of five intertwined rings, each of a different colour, representing the five continents of the world as Blue ring - Europe; Yellow ring - Asia; Black ring - Africa; Red ring- America; Green ring - Oceania. It represents the five continents of the world, united by Olympism, while the six colours are those that appear on all the national flags of the world at the present time.

questions.Question: Name the instrument used to measure relative humidity
questions.solution: Solution:		Hygrometer is the instrument used to measure relative humidity. Humidity is the measure of the amount of moisture in the air.

questions.Question: Kathak, Nauntanki, Jhora and Kajri are the important dances of
questions.solution: Solution:		Kathak, Nauntanki, Jhora and Kajri are the important dances of Uttar Pradesh.

questions.Question: Lance Armstrong, a sportsperson of international repute, belongs to which of the following countries?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lance Edward Armstrong (born Lance Edward Gunderson on September 18, 1971) is an American professional road racing cyclist who is best known for winning the Tour de France a record seven consecutive times, after having survived testicular cancer.

questions.Question: Ludhiana is situated on ____ river.
questions.solution: Solution:		Ludhiana is situated on Satluj river. The city stands on the Sutlej River's old bank, 13 kilometres (8.1 mi) south of its present course. It is an industrial center of northern India; the UK's BBC has called it India's Manchester. Ludhiana was among the list of smart cities that will be developed by government of India.

questions.Question: Kiran Bedi is
questions.solution: Solution:		Kiran Bedi is first woman IPS officer. Kiran Bedi (born 9 June 1949) is a retired Indian Police Service officer, social activist, former tennis player and politician who is the current Lieutenant Governor of Puducherry. She is the first female Indian Police Service (IPS) officer and started her serivce in 1975.

questions.Question: K.S. Ranjit Singhji was
questions.solution: Solution:		K.S. Ranjit Singhji was first Indian test cricketer. Born on 10 September, 1872, in Kathiawar in modern-day Gujarat, Ranji was the first person of Indian origin to play Test cricket when he made his debut for England in 1896.

questions.Question: The term which refers to the total amount of sales made by a firm in one year or the total amount of money changing hands in business, is
questions.solution: Solution:		The term which refers to the total amount of sales made by a firm in one year or the total amount of money changing hands in business, is turnover. Sales turnover represents the value of total sales provided to customers during a specified time period, which is usually one year. The amount includes only revenue that is generated from daily operations, not non-operating revenue.

questions.Question: Treaty of Versailles rearranged the boundaries of several countries in Europe and many countries were formed such as
questions.solution: Solution:		Treaty of Versailles rearranged the boundaries of several countries in Europe and many countries were formed such as Poland and Yugoslavia and Lithuania and Estonia.

questions.Question: The tribe residing in Meghalaya is
questions.solution: Solution:		The tribe residing in Meghalaya is Garos. The Garos refer to themselves as A'chik or Mande and their language belongs to the Bodo branch of the Bodo-Naga-Kachin family of Sino Tibetan phylum.

questions.Question: The UN charter was finalized at ___ and become effective on ___ .
questions.solution: Solution:		The Charter of the United Nations was signed on 26 June 1945, in San Francisco, at the conclusion of the United Nations Conference on International Organization, and came into force on 24 October 1945. The Statute of the International Court of Justice is an integral part of the Charter.

questions.Question: The total number of members of UN Security Council is
questions.solution: Solution:		The Council is composed of 15 Members: Five permanent members: China, France, Russian Federation, the United Kingdom, and the United States, and ten non-permanent members.

questions.Question: Soil is formed from the parent rock material by
questions.solution: Solution:		Soil is formed from the parent rock material by chemical decomposition, physical decomposition and biological decomposition.

questions.Question: The air we inhale is mixture of gases. Which of the following gases in the mixture is highest in percentage?
questions.solution: Solution:		The air we inhale is mixture of gases. Nitrogen of the following gases in the mixture is highest in percentage. Inhaled air is by volume 78.08% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen and small amounts include argon, carbon dioxide, neon, helium, and hydrogen.

questions.Question: Oxford university was founded in
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxford university was founded in 1163 AD. The University of Oxford is a collegiate research university in Oxford, England.

questions.Question: The American General who led the revolt against the British and declared American independence was
questions.solution: Solution:		The American General who led the revolt against the British and declared American independence was George Washington.

questions.Question: Regular meetings of Trusteeship Council (UNO) are held
questions.solution: Solution:		Regular meetings of Trusteeship Council (UNO) are held twice a year. The United Nations Trusteeship Council is one of the six principal organs of the United Nations, established to help ensure that trust territories were administered in the best interests of their inhabitants and of international peace and security.

questions.Question: Triple antigen provides immunity to children against all of the following disease, except
questions.solution: Solution:		Triple antigen provides immunity to children against all of the following disease, except polio. Polio, short for poliomyelitis, or infantile paralysis, is an infectious disease caused by the poliovirus. In about 0.5 percent of cases, there is muscle weakness resulting in an inability to move.

questions.Question: Trans World Airlines is an International Airline of
questions.solution: Solution:		Trans World Airlines is an International Airline of United States of America. TWA was headquartered at one time in Kansas City, Missouri, and planned to make Kansas City International Airport its main domestic and international hub, but abandoned this plan in the 1970s. The airline later developed its largest hub at Lambert-St. Louis International Airport.

questions.Question: The third crusade was led by
questions.solution: Solution:		The third crusade was led by Richard I of England,Fredrick Barbarossa of Germany and Philip II of France.

questions.Question: Walt Disney was
questions.optionA: the President of America during World War I
questions.optionB: the greater of cartoon films starring popular cartoon characters Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck
questions.optionC: the British physician known for his discovery of Addison's disease
questions.solution: Solution:		Walt Disney was the greater of cartoon films starring popular cartoon characters Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck. Walt Disney , in full Walter Elias Disney, (born December 5, 1901, Chicago, Illinois, U.S.—died December 15, 1966, Los Angeles, California), American motion-picture and television producer and showman, famous as a pioneer of animated cartoon films and as the creator of such cartoon characters as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.

questions.Question: To consider the large number of agenda items, General Assembly has how many main committees?
questions.solution: Solution:		To consider the large number of agenda items, General Assembly has seven main committees. Each committee deals with a particular topic and is allocated agenda items according to the topic. A report is issued to the plenary for each item allocated to a Main Committee.

questions.Question: National Institute of Oceanography is located at
questions.solution: Solution:		National Institute of Oceanography is located at Panaji (Goa). The National Institute of Oceanography (NIO) with its headquarters at Dona Paula, Goa, and regional centres at Kochi, Mumbai and Visakhapatnam, is one of the 37 constituent laboratories of the Council of Scientific & Industrial Research (CSIR), New Delhi.

questions.Question: Nuclear power is ____ thermal power.
questions.solution: Solution:		Nuclear power is cheaper than thermal power. Nuclear power plants are expensive to build but relatively cheap to run. In many places, nuclear energy is competitive with fossil fuels as a means of electricity generation. Waste disposal and decommissioning costs are usually fully included in the operating costs.

questions.Question: Michael Faraday discovered
questions.optionB: benzene, liquid gases and optical glass
questions.solution: Solution:		Michael Faraday discovered electromagnetism,benzene, liquid gases and optical glass and the induction of electric current. Michael Faraday was an English scientist who contributed to the study of electromagnetism and electrochemistry. His main discoveries include the principles underlying electromagnetic induction, diamagnetism and electrolysis.

questions.Question: Mother Teresa won the Nobel Prize for Peace in
questions.solution: Solution:		Mother Teresa won the Nobel Prize for Peace in 1979. In 1979, Teresa received the Nobel Peace Prize "for work undertaken in the struggle to overcome poverty and distress, which also constitutes a threat to peace".

questions.Question: Most commonly used bleaching agent is
questions.solution: Solution:		Most commonly used bleaching agent is chlorine. The most widely used bleach in the United States is liquid chlorine bleach, an alkaline aqueous solution of sodium hypochlorite.

questions.Question: Hundred year war was fought between
questions.solution: Solution:		Hundred year war was fought between France and England during the late Middle Ages. It lasted 116 years from 1337 to 1453. The war started because Charles IV of France died in 1328 without an immediate male heir (i.e., a son or younger brother).

questions.Question: In which of the following pairs, the two substances forming the pair are chemically most dissimilar?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Butter and paraffin wax, the two substances forming the pair are chemically most dissimilar. Butter is an unsaturated compound or an olefin in contrast to wax which is a saturated compound. So butter will show more reactivity for reactants. As such, they show different chemical nature.

questions.Question: India's Integrated Missiles Development Programme was started in ____ under the chairmanship of Dr.  A.P.J. Abdul Kalam.
questions.solution: Solution:		India's Integrated Missiles Development Programme was started in 1982-83 under the chairmanship of Dr.A.P.J. Abdul Kalam. On 8 January 2008, the DRDO formally announced the successful completion of the IGMDP.

questions.Question: INS Agrani (Petty Officers' School) is situated at
questions.solution: Solution:		INS Agrani (Petty Officers' School) is situated at Coimbatore. Indian Naval Station Agrani is a leadership training establishment of the Indian Navy, it comes under the Eastern Naval Command and conducts courses for middle level sailors. This station was commissioned in 1965.

questions.Question: Hybridization is
questions.optionB: a process of tilling the land
questions.optionD: downward movement of water through soil
questions.solution: Solution:		Hybridization is cross-fertilization between two varieties. Hybridization refers to the natural or deliberate pollination between two plants. It occurs all the time in the wild as many plants are cross-pollinated and when the pollen from one plant lands on the stigma of another plant, and if fertilization is successful in producing seed, then hybridization has occurred.

questions.Question: Which language of India belongs to Dravidian family?
questions.solution: Solution:		Languages of Southern India belongs to Dravidian family. The largest group is South Dravidian, with almost 150 million speakers. Tamil, Malayalam, and Kannada make up around 98% of the speakers, with Tamil being by far the most spoken language, with almost half of all South Dravidian speakers speaking it.

questions.Question: Which of the following became the first black President of South Africa?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nelson Mandela became the first black President of South Africa. Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela (18 July 1918 – 5 December 2013) was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary, political leader, and philanthropist who served as President of South Africa from 1994 to 1999. He was the country's first black head of state and the first elected in a fully representative democratic election.

questions.Question: Which of the following cities of Maharashtra have airports?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mumbai, Nagpur, Pune, Manmad, Sholapur and Akola have airports.

questions.Question: Where did last world cup soccer tournament took place (2010)?
questions.solution: Solution:		In South Africa, last world cup soccer tournament took place (2010). The 2010 FIFA World Cup was the 19th FIFA World Cup, the world championship for men's national association football teams. It took place in South Africa from 11 June to 11 July 2010. The bidding process for hosting the tournament finals was open only to African nations.

questions.Question: When was Ranasingha Premadasa, President of Sri Lanka, assassinated?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1993, Ranasingha Premadasa, President of Sri Lanka, assassinated.

questions.Question: Guwahati High Court is the judicature of
questions.solution: Solution:		Guwahati High Court is the judicature of Assam, Nagaland and Arunachal Pradesh.

questions.Question: Friction can be reduced by changing from
questions.solution: Solution:		Friction can be reduced by changing from sliding to rolling. Replace sliding friction with rolling element friction, such as with the use of rolling element bearings.

questions.Question: During eleventh Antarctic Expedition in Nov. 1991/March 1992 ____ was installed.
questions.solution: Solution:		SODAR (Sonic Detection And Ranging), also written as sodar, is a meteorological instrument also known as a wind profiler which measures the scattering of sound waves by atmospheric turbulence.

questions.Question: From the following, choose the set in which names of Secretary-Generals of the UNO are arranged in correct chronological order?
questions.optionA: Trygve Lie, Dag Hammarskjoeld, U Thant, Kurt Waldheim.
questions.optionB: U Thant, Dag Hammarskjoeld, Trygve Lie, Kurt Waldheim.
questions.optionC: U Thant, Kurt Waldheim, Dag Hammarskjoeld, Trygve Lie.
questions.optionD: Trygve Lie, U Thant , Dag Hammarskjoeld, Kurt Waldheim.
questions.solution: Solution:		Trygve Lie, Dag Hammarskjoeld, U Thant, Kurt Waldheim is the correct chronological order of names of Secretary-Generals of the UNO.

questions.Question: Fire temple is the place of worship of which of the following religion?
questions.solution: Solution:		Fire temple is the place of worship of Zoroastrianism (Parsi Religion). A fire temple in Zoroastrianism is the place of worship for Zoroastrians, often called dar-e mehr (Persian) or agiyari (Gujarati). In the Zoroastrian religion, fire (see atar), together with clean water (see aban), are agents of ritual purity.

questions.Question: To produce sound it is necessary that
questions.optionA: the source should execute longitudinal vibrations
questions.optionB: the source should execute transverse vibrations
questions.optionC: the source may execute any type of vibrations
questions.optionD: the vibrations of source are not necessary
questions.solution: Solution:		To produce sound it is necessary that the source may execute any type of vibrations. Sound requires material medium for its propagation. It is produced when a body vibrates. The vibrations produced at a point are transmitted in the medium (air) from one point to the next and so on in the form of mechanical waves which produce compressions and rarefactions in air.

questions.Question: The UN library is known by the name of
questions.solution: Solution:		The UN library is known by the name of Hammarskjoeld library. The Dag Hammarskjöld Library is a library on the grounds of the headquarters of the United Nations, located in the Turtle Bay/East Midtown neighborhood of Manhattan, in New York City. It is connected to the Secretariat and Conference buildings through ground level and underground corridors. It is named after Dag Hammarskjöld, the second Secretary-General of the United Nations.

questions.Question: The theory of inheritance of acquired character was propounded by
questions.solution: Solution:		The theory of inheritance of acquired character was propounded by J.B. Lamarck. Lamarck is best known for his Theory of Inheritance of Acquired Characteristics, first presented in 1801 (Darwin's first book dealing with natural selection was published in 1859): If an organism changes during life in order to adapt to its environment, those changes are passed on to its offspring.

questions.Question: Water is a good solvent of ionic salts because
questions.optionA: it has a high boiling point
questions.optionB: it has  a high dipole moment
questions.optionC: it has a high specific heat
questions.solution: Solution:		Water is a good solvent of ionic salts because it has a high dipole moment. Salts are ionic compounds which, when dissolved in water, break up completely into ions. They arise by the reaction of acids with bases, and they always contain either a metal cation or a cation derived from ammonium (NH4+).

questions.Question: Vijayalakshmi Pandit was
questions.optionA: the first women minister of an Indian state (UP)

questions.optionC: the first Indian women Ambassador to Moscow
questions.solution: Solution:		Vijayalakshmi Pandit was the first women minister of an Indian state (UP), the first women to become president of the UN General Assembly and the first Indian women Ambassador to Moscow.

questions.Question: If force is expressed in Newton and the distance in metre, then the work done is expressed in
questions.solution: Solution:		If force is expressed in Newton and the distance in metre, then the work done is expressed in Joule. Work done is expressed in force divided by distance. SI unit is joule.

questions.Question: How many teeth does a normal adult dog have?
questions.solution: Solution:		Adult dogs have 42 permanent teeth compared to a measly 32 average human teeth (not counting any wisdom teeth. Those are "bonus"). Puppies possess 28 baby teeth while human babies will have 20 deciduous or “baby” teeth.

questions.Question: How many red blood cells does the bone marrow produce every second?
questions.solution: Solution:		10 million red blood cells the bone marrow produce every second. The formation of a red blood cell from hemocytoblast takes about 2 days. The body makes about two million red blood cells every second.

questions.Question: How many times has Brazil won the World Cup Football Championship?
questions.solution: Solution:		Brazil have won five times, and they are the only team to have played in every tournament. The other World Cup winners are Germany and Italy, with four titles each; Argentina, France and inaugural winner Uruguay, with two titles each; and England and Spain with one title each.

questions.Question: If speed of rotation of the earth increases, weight of the body
questions.solution: Solution:		If speed of rotation of the earth increases, weight of the body decreases. This is because you see a moving body on the rotating earth's surface itself is in the reference frame. So when the earth rotates, the centripetal force acts towards the centre of rotation.

questions.Question:
Nowadays many novel chemicals are being synthesized termed as xenobiotics. The unique feature of these is what they are 

I.biodegradable
II.non- biodegradable
III.pose on environmental threat
IV.they are environment friendly
questions.solution: Solution:		Nowadays many novel chemicals are being synthesized termed as xenobiotics. The unique feature of these are that they are non- biodegradable and pose on environmental threat.

questions.Question: Modern Indo-Aryan languages are based on an ancient language called
questions.solution: Solution:		Modern Indo-Aryan languages are based on an ancient language called Sanskrit. The Indo-Aryan or Indic languages are a major language family of South Asia (or the Indian subcontinent). They constitute a branch of the Indo-Iranian languages, itself a branch of the Indo-European language family.

questions.Question: Lakshmibai National College of Physical Education is located at
questions.solution: Solution:		Lakshmibai National College of Physical Education is located at Gwalior. The Lakshmibai National Institute of Physical Education is a Government of India sponsored deemed university, under the Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports, dedicated to promoting excellence in sports and physical education in the country. The campus is on the Agra - Mumbai National Highway at Shaktinagar, Gwalior in the state of Madhya Pradesh, India.

questions.Question: Malfunctioning of which of the following organs causes jaundice?
questions.solution: Solution:		Malfunctioning of liver organ causes jaundice. Hepatocellular jaundice occurs as a result of liver disease or injury. Hemolytic jaundice occurs as a result of hemolysis, or an accelerated breakdown of red blood cells, leading to an increase in production of bilirubin. Obstructive jaundice occurs as a result of an obstruction in the bile duct.

questions.Question: Olympic creed and oath was composed by ____ the founder of modern Olympics.
questions.solution: Solution:		Olympic creed and oath was composed by Baron Pierre de Coubertin the founder of modern Olympics. Charles Pierre de Frédy, Baron de Coubertin was a French educator and historian, founder of the International Olympic Committee, and its second President. He is known as the father of the modern Olympic Games.

questions.Question: The term of office of a Judge of the International Court of Justice is
questions.solution: Solution:		The term of office of a Judge of the International Court of Justice is nine years. The International Court of Justice is composed of 15 judges elected to nine-year terms of office by the United Nations General Assembly and the Security Council. These organs vote simultaneously but separately. In order to be elected, a candidate must receive an absolute majority of the votes in both bodies.

questions.Question: UNESCO (United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organisation) was established in
questions.solution: Solution:		UNESCO (United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organisation) was established in 1946.At the end of the conference, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was founded and the Constitution of UNESCO, signed on 16 November 1945, came into force on 4 November 1946.

questions.Question: The Treaty of Versailles was signed in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Treaty ended the state of war between Germany and the Allied Powers. It was signed on 28 June 1919 in Versailles, exactly five years after the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, which had directly led to the war. The other Central Powers on the German side signed separate treaties.

questions.Question: The temporary suspension of hostilities by mutual consent in order to stout a peace negotiation is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The temporary suspension of hostilities by mutual consent in order to stout a peace negotiation is called armistice. An armistice is a formal agreement of warring parties to stop fighting. It is not necessarily the end of a war, as it may constitute only a cessation of hostilities while an attempt is made to negotiate a lasting peace. It is derived from the Latin arma, meaning "arms" and -stitium, meaning "a stopping".

questions.Question: The UN Flag is made up of
