questions.solution: Solution:		Hygrometer is used to measure relative humidity. Humidity is the measure of the amount of moisture in the air. A psychrometer is an example of a hygrometer.

questions.Question: India became a member of the United Nations in
questions.solution: Solution:		India became a member of the United Nations in 1945. India is a founding member of the United Nations. On June 26, 1945, India was among 50 countries to sign the UN charter. India joined the United Nations after ratifying the UN Charter on October 30, 1945.

questions.Question: India has
questions.solution: Solution:		India has largest turmeric production, largest tea production and largest ginger production.

questions.Question: India's first indigenously built submarine was
questions.solution: Solution:		INS Shalki (S46) is a Shishumar-class diesel-electric submarine of the Indian Navy. The submarine was the first ever submarine to be built in India. It was launched in 1987 by the late Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

questions.Question: In Air Force, Air Commodore has one rank higher than
questions.solution: Solution:		In Air Force, Air Commodore has one rank higher than Group Captain. Air commodore is a one-star rank and the most junior air officer rank, being immediately senior to group captain and immediately subordinate to air vice-marshal. It has a NATO ranking code of OF-6 and is equivalent to a commodore in the Royal Navy or a brigadier in the British Army or the Royal Marines.

questions.Question: How much districts are there in Tamil Nadu?
questions.solution: Solution:		There are 33 districts in Tamil Nadu.

questions.Question: How much districts are there in Meghalaya?
questions.solution: Solution:		Meghalaya currently has 11 districts.

questions.Question: How many Dynes are there in 1 gram weight?
questions.solution: Solution:		There are 981 dynes in one gram weight. Dyne is a CGS unit.

questions.Question: In big cities like Delhi, Kolkata, Mumbai, Chennai police is headed by a
questions.solution: Solution:		In big cities like Delhi, Kolkata, Mumbai, Chennai police is headed by a Commissioner of Police. Police commissioners serve their communities by overseeing police departments, either as sworn officers or as civilians selected to sit on a board of police commissioners.

questions.Question: The ruling party of Singapore, where no opposition parties are allowed is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The ruling party of Singapore, where no opposition parties are allowed is called People's Action Party. The governing party since 1959, it was founded in 1954 as a pro-independence political party descended from an earlier student organization, and it has gone on to dominate the political system of the nation. The PAP has dominated Singapore's politics and has been credited as being central to the city-state's rapid political, social and economic development.

questions.Question: The restoration of the Olympic Games at the end of the last century was at the initiative of a/an
questions.solution: Solution:		The restoration of the Olympic Games at the end of the last century was at the initiative of a French baron. The title of baron was assumed as a titre de courtoisie by many nobles, whether members of the Nobles of the Robe or cadets of Nobles of the Sword who held no title in their own right.

questions.Question: The national sport of Canada is
questions.solution: Solution:		The national sport of Canada is lacrosse. Lacrosse was declared Canada's national game in 1859. However, in 1994, Canadian Parliament passed Canada's National Sport Act, which made lacrosse the national summer sport, and hockey the national winter sport.

questions.Question: The Prize that is awarded every two years to people who have worded for "Freedom of speech", is
questions.solution: Solution:		The Prize that is awarded every two years to people who have worded for "Freedom of speech", is Monismanien Swedish. Monismanien Prize for freedom of speech was founded by Swedish filmmaker Kenne Fant in 1975. Fant's movie Monismanien 1995 is set in a fictive post-World War III totalitarian state of the same name and portrays the effects of suppression of freedom of expression.

questions.Question: The origin of modern badminton is attributed to
questions.solution: Solution:		The origin of modern badminton is attributed to Britain. Modern badminton was started in mid 19th century. It was played by British officers in India.

questions.Question: When was Mona Lisa painted by Leonardo da Vinci?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mona Lisa was painted by Leonardo da Vinci in 1504 AD. Leonardo da Vinci is thought to have begun painting the Mona Lisa in 1503 or 1504 in Florence, Italy. Although the Louvre states that it was "doubtless painted between 1503 and 1506", the art historian Martin Kemp says there are some difficulties in confirming the actual dates with certainty.

questions.Question: Which of the following agencies related to the United Nation was in existence before the Second World War?
questions.solution: Solution:		International Labour Organisation is related to the United Nation was in existence before the Second World War. The International Labour Organization is a United Nations agency whose mandate is to advance social justice and promote decent work by setting international labour standards. It was the first specialised agency of the UN.

questions.Question: Which is the state with largest urban population?
questions.solution: Solution:		In terms of absolute number of persons living in urban areas, Maharashtra continues to lead with 50.8 million persons which comprises 13.5 percent of the total urban population of the country. Uttar Pradesh accounts for about 44.4 million, followed by Tamil Nadu at 34.9 million.

questions.Question: Which of the following are the important sects of Islam?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sunnis and Shias are the important sects of Islam. Shia and Sunni Islam are the two major denominations of Islam. They chose sides following the death of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in AD 632.

questions.Question: Where is the sports stadium, Green Park, located?
questions.solution: Solution:		Green Park is the sports stadium, located in Kanpur. Green Park Stadium is a 32,000 capacity floodlit cricket stadium located in Kanpur, India, and home to the Uttar Pradesh cricket team. The stadium is under the control of the Sports Department Uttar Pradesh.

questions.Question: The country, which was admitted to the membership of the United Nations in September 2002, is
questions.solution: Solution:		The country, which was admitted to the membership of the United Nations in September 2002, is East Timor. On 27 September 2002, East Timor was renamed to Timor-Leste, using the Portuguese language, and was admitted as a member state by the UN.

questions.Question: The committee of the Norwegian Parliament awards the prize for
questions.solution: Solution:		The committee of the Norwegian Parliament awards the prize for peace. The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded by a committee of five, appointed by the Storting (the Norwegian parliament). The Norwegian Nobel Committee 2019.

questions.Question: The date of operation of first open heart surgery in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The date of operation of first open heart surgery in India was February 15, 1961. "It was in Nair Hospital on February 15, 1961, that Dr K N Dastur performed the country's first open-heart surgery to fix the hole in 19-year-old Hemlata's heart,'' said Nair Hospital dean Dr R Rananavre on Tuesday.

questions.Question: The first Indian to be awarded the Oscar for lifetime achievements in Cinema in 1992 was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Indian to be awarded the Oscar for lifetime achievements in cinema in 1992 was Satyajit Ray. Satyajit Ray won the National Award for the Best Director six times, which is the most by any filmmaker so far. In total, he won 32 National Awards by the Government of India. Satyajit Ray received an Honorary Academy Award in 1992, becoming the first Indian to receive an Honorary Oscars.

questions.Question: The element of an electric stove made
questions.solution: Solution:		The element of an electric stove made nicrome. Nichrome 80/20 is an ideal material, because it has relatively high resistance and forms an adherent layer of chromium oxide when it is heated for the first time.

questions.Question: The velocity of light was first measured by
questions.solution: Solution:		The velocity of light was first measured by Romer. The first measurements of the speed of light using completely terrestrial apparatus were published in 1849 by Hippolyte Fizeau (1819–96). Compared to values accepted today, Fizeau's result (about 313,000 kilometres per second) was too high, and less accurate than those obtained by Rømer's method.

questions.Question: The trophies and cups awarded for cricket are
questions.optionA: McDowell's Challenge cup and World cup
questions.solution: Solution:		The trophies and cups awarded for cricket are McDowell's Challenge cup and World cup.

questions.Question: The third highest nation award given for distinguished service in any field is
questions.solution: Solution:		The third highest nation award given for distinguished service in any field is Padma Shri. The Padma Bhushan is the third-highest civilian award in the Republic of India, preceded by the Bharat Ratna and the Padma Vibhushan and followed by the Padma Shri.

questions.Question: The term used in billiards are
questions.optionA: blocking, held ball, holding, jump ball, pivot
questions.optionC: auxiliary point system, rabbit punch, break, cut
questions.optionD: blank line, break, bolting, cannon, cue, hazard, in-oft
questions.solution: Solution:		The term used in billiards are blank line, break, bolting, cannon, cue, hazard, in-oft. Billiards, any of various games played on a rectangular table with a designated number of small balls and a long stick called a cue. The table and the cushioned rail bordering the table are topped with a feltlike tight-fitting cloth. Carom, or French, billiards is played with three balls on a table that has no pockets.

questions.Question: Vir Chakra (a medal) is made up of
questions.solution: Solution:		Vir Chakra (a medal) is made up of standard silver. Vir Chakra is an Indian gallantry award presented for acts of gallantry in the presence of the enemy on the battlefield. It replaced the British Distinguished Service Cross (DSC), Military Cross (MC) and Distinguished Flying Cross (DFC).

questions.Question: The telescope is used for viewing
questions.solution: Solution:		The telescope is used for viewing distant objects. Telescopes are meant for viewing distant objects, producing an image that is larger than the image that can be seen with the unaided eye. Telescopes gather far more light than the eye, allowing dim objects to be observed with greater magnification and better resolution.

questions.Question: The transport fleet of Air Force consists of
questions.solution: Solution:		The transport fleet of Air Force consists of IL-765, Boeing-731 and AN-352.

questions.Question: The term butterfly is associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		The term butterfly is associated with swimming. The butterfly (colloquially shortened to fly) is a swimming stroke swum on the chest, with both arms moving symmetrically, accompanied by the butterfly kick (also known as the "dolphin kick").

questions.Question: Venturi tube is used for
questions.solution: Solution:		Venturi tube is used for measuring flow of a fluid. Venturi tube, short pipe with a constricted inner surface, used to measure fluid flows and as a pump.

questions.Question: Uttar Pradesh is surrounded by ___ in north
questions.solution: Solution:		Uttar Pradesh is surrounded by Uttarakhand in north. Uttar Pradesh is bordered by the state of Uttarakhand and the country of Nepal to the north, the state of Bihar to the east, the states of Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh to the southeast, the state of Madhya Pradesh to the south, and the states of Rajasthan and Haryana and the national capital territory of Delhi to the west.

questions.Question: Which day is " World Teachers Day"?
questions.solution: Solution:		World Teachers' Day, also known as International Teachers Day, is held every year on October 5 to honor teachers and recognize their contributions to education and development. Many events are organized on this day (or a day around this date if necessary to avoid school holidays) to emphasize the importance of teachers and learning and to raise the profile and increase the awareness and understanding of the teaching profession and its importance.

questions.Question: Which of the following nations is a member of G-8?
questions.solution: Solution:		Canada is a member of G-8. Members are Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States.

questions.Question:
Arjuna Award is given for
.
questions.solution: Solution:		Arjuna Award is given for outstanding performance in sports. It was started in 1961, the award carries a cash prize of ₹500,000, a bronze statue of Arjuna and a scroll.

questions.Question: "Swaraj is my birth right and I shall have it." This was advocated by
questions.solution: Solution:		"Swaraj is my birth right and I shall have it." This was advocated by Bal Gangadhar Tilak. The slogan popularised by Bal Gangadhar Tilak, the fiery freedom fighter of India, is one of the most potent war cries of the pre-independence days. This simple sentence is loaded with meaning, emotion, conviction and a strong sense of action.

questions.Question: Coal mines in Jharkhand are located at:
questions.solution: Solution:		Coal mines in Jharkhand are located at Jharia. In Jharkhand, Jharia in Dhanbad is the Coal Capital of India apart from this You will find the Coal mines in Girdih,Ramgarh,Dumka and Bokaro. India's Largest Coalfield is in Raniganj,West Bengal.

questions.Question: Which Academy promotes and develops literature in all the 22 languages of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sahitya Academy promotes and develops literature in all the 22 languages of India. The Sahitya Akademi, India's National Academy of Letters, is an organisation dedicated to the promotion of literature in the languages of India. Founded on 12 March 1954, it is supported by, though independent of, the Indian government.

questions.Question: Which of the following agencies related to the United Nations is concerned with promoting the growth of international trade and equilibrium in balance of payments?
questions.optionC: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development Organisation
questions.solution: Solution:		International Bank for Reconstruction and Development Organisation agencies related to the United Nations is concerned with promoting the growth of international trade and equilibrium in balance of payments. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), commonly referred to as the World Bank, is an international financial institution whose purposes include assisting the development of its member nation’s territories, promoting and supplementing private foreign investment and promoting long-range balance growth in international trade.

questions.Question: Which of the following are the members of CARICOM?
questions.optionB: Barbados, Belize, St. Lucia, St. Vincent
questions.solution: Solution:		Angrilla, Antigua, Trinidad, Tobago, Barbados, Belize, St. Lucia, St. Vincent, Dommica, Grenade, Guyana and Jamaica are the members of CARICOM.

questions.Question: When was the International Monetary Fund established?
questions.solution: Solution:		The IMF formally came into existence on 27 December 1945, when the first 29 countries ratified its Articles of Agreement.

questions.Question: Which company carries the construction of submarines, missile-boats and destroyers and so on for the India navy and offshore supply vessels and well-head platforms and so on?
questions.optionB: Garden Reach Shipbuilders and Engineering Limited (GRSE)
questions.solution: Solution:		Mazgaon Dock Limited (MDL) company carries the construction of submarines, missile-boats and destroyers and so on for the India navy and offshore supply vessels and well-head platforms and so on. It manufactures warships and submarines for the Indian Navy and offshore platforms and associated support vessels for offshore oil drilling.

questions.Question: The term used when a member of a legislature leaves his party on whose ticket he was elected to join the ruling party or the opposition, is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The term used when a member of a legislature leaves his party on whose ticket he was elected to join the ruling party or the opposition, is called floor crossing. In politics, a politician is said to cross the floor if they change their party allegiance. Crossing the floor may mean changing to second party after being elected as a member of a first party, or voting against the approved party lines.

questions.Question: The term hit wicket in cricket refers to
questions.optionA: when the bowler bowls out three batsman with three successive balls
questions.optionB: when the batsman intercepts the ball with his leg or any part of his body between the wicket
questions.optionC: when the batsman, while hitting the ball, strikes his own wicket with his bat or body and is declared out
questions.solution: Solution:		The term hit wicket in cricket refers to when the batsman, while hitting the ball, strikes his own wicket with his bat or body and is declared out. Cricket rules specify that if a batsman hits his wicket down with his bat or body after the bowler has entered his delivery stried and the ball is in play then he is out. The striking batsman is also out if he hits his wicket down while setting off for his first run.

questions.Question: Under article 61 of the UN Charter, the membership of the Economic and Social Council was which of the following years from 27 to 54?
questions.solution: Solution:		Under article 61 of the UN Charter, the membership of the Economic and Social Council was 1973 years from 27 to 54. Expansion of the UN Economic and Social Council from 27 to 54 members by an amendment to Article 61 of the Charter, which was adopted by the General Assembly in 1971 and became operative on 24 September 1973.

questions.Question: WTO, (World Trade Organization), WHO, (World Health Organization) and IDA (International Development Association) are ___ of General Assembly (UNO).
questions.optionC: specialized agencies and other autonomous organization
questions.optionD: they are independent agencies and not a part of UNO
questions.solution: Solution:		WTO, (World Trade Organization), WHO, (World Health Organization) and IDA (International Development Association) are specialized agencies and other autonomous organization of General Assembly (UNO).

questions.Question: When light passes from air into glass it experiences change of
questions.solution: Solution:		When light passes from air into glass it experiences change of wavelength and speed. Waves change speed when they pass across the boundary between two different substances, such as light waves refracting when they pass from air to glass. This causes them to change direction and this effect is called refraction.

questions.Question: For which of the following disciplines is Nobel Prize awarded?
questions.solution: Solution:		For Literature, Peace and Economics, Physics and Chemistry and Physiology or Medicine of the following disciplines the Nobel Prize is awarded.

questions.Question: Hitler party which came into power in 1933 is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Hitler party which came into power in 1933 is known as Nazi Party. Under the leadership of Adolf Hitler (1889-1945), the National Socialist German Workers’ Party, or Nazi Party, grew into a mass movement and ruled Germany through totalitarian means from 1933 to 1945. Founded in 1919 as the German Workers’ Party, the group promoted German pride and anti-Semitism, and expressed dissatisfaction with the terms of the Treaty of Versailles, the 1919 peace settlement that ended World War I (1914-1918) and required Germany to make numerous concessions and reparations.

questions.Question: FFC stands for
questions.solution: Solution:		FFC stands for Film Finance Corporation. FFC, is India's state funding body for films. The 1927 Indian Cinematograph Committee recommended such a state-sponsored agency in its Report of the Indian Cinematograph Committee.

questions.Question: Fastest shorthand writer was
questions.solution: Solution:		Fastest shorthand writer was Dr. G. D. Bist.

questions.Question: Epsom (England) is the place associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		Epsom (England) is the place associated with Horse racing. Epsom is a market town in Surrey, England, 22.0 km south-west of London. Epsom Downs Racecourse holds The Derby, now a generic name for sports competitions in English-speaking countries. The town also gives its name to Epsom salts, extracted from mineral waters there.

questions.Question: Of the UN Agencies, which one specifically aims at further economic development by encouraging productive private enterprise?
questions.solution: Solution:		Of the UN Agencies, International Finance Corporation is one specifically aims at further economic development by encouraging productive private enterprise. International Finance Corporation is a private equity and venture capital subsidiary focused on the private sector in developing countries.

questions.Question: Neil Armstrong and Edwin Aldrin were the first to
questions.solution: Solution:		Neil Armstrong and Edwin Aldrin were the first to step on the moon. Apollo 11 was the spaceflight that first landed humans on the Moon. Commander Neil Armstrong and lunar module pilot Buzz Aldrin formed the American crew that landed the Apollo Lunar Module Eagle on July 20, 1969, at 20:17 UTC. Armstrong became the first person to step onto the lunar surface six hours and 39 minutes later on July 21 at 02:56 UTC; Aldrin joined him 19 minutes later.

questions.Question: Lal Bahadur Shastri is also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Lal Bahadur Shastri is also known as Man of Peace. The nation recalled the man of peace - Lal Bahadur Shastri on the occasion of his death anniversary on Friday.

questions.Question: Lime is sometimes applied to soil in order to
questions.optionA: increase the alkalinity of the soil
questions.optionB: increase the acidity of the soil
questions.solution: Solution:		Lime is sometimes applied to soil in order to increase the alkalinity of the soil. It increases the pH of acidic soil (the lower the pH the more acidic the soil); in other words, soil acidity is reduced and alkalinity increased. it provides a source of calcium and magnesium for plants. It permits improved water penetration for acidic soils.

questions.Question: Magsaysay awards are named after Ramon Magsaysay, ____ who was known for his land reform programme to defuse communist insurgency.
questions.solution: Solution:		Magsaysay awards are named after Ramon Magsaysay, President of the Philippines who was known for his land reform programme to defuse communist insurgency. Ramon del Fierro Magsaysay was a Filipino statesman who served as the seventh President of the Philippines, from December 30, 1953 until his death in an aircraft disaster.

questions.Question: Until December 1991 ____ were integral parts of the USSR & not independent countries, but had separate UN memberships.
questions.solution: Solution:		Until December 1991 Belarus and Ukraine were integral parts of the USSR & not independent countries, but had separate UN memberships. Though Belarus and Ukraine have a long shared history, the two countries differ significantly in many ways.

questions.Question: Weight of an object put in a satellite orbiting in space around the earth is
questions.optionA: the same as on the earth
questions.optionB: slightly more than that on the earth
questions.optionC: less than that on the earth
questions.solution: Solution:		Weight of an object put in a satellite orbiting in space around the earth is reduced to zero. The satellite will fly off into space in a direction which was tangential to its original direction of motion. This is because the direction of velocity of an object moving in a circular path is always tangential at every point along the path.

questions.Question: To which country did the first Secretary-General of the UN belong?
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Secretary-General of the UN belong to Norway. LIE, Trygve Halvdan, Norwegian politician and first Secretary-General of the United Nations 1946-1953, was born 16 July 1896 in Kristiania (now Oslo), Norway and passed away 30 December 1968 in Geilo, Norway.

questions.Question: War of the Roses was
questions.optionB: religious-cum-political war between the Lutherans Catholics in Germany
questions.optionC: war between Syrian and Roman forces
questions.solution: Solution:		War of the Roses was civil war in England. The Wars of the Roses were a series of English civil wars for control of the throne of England fought between supporters of two rival cadet branches of the royal House of Plantagenet: the House of Lancaster, represented by a red rose, and the House of York, represented by a white rose.

questions.Question: The three abundant elements in the earth's crust are aluminium, oxygen and silicon. The correct order of their abundance is
questions.solution: Solution:		The three abundant elements in the earth's crust are oxygen, silicon, aluminium. The mass-abundance of the nine most abundant elements in the Earth's crust is approximately: oxygen 46%, silicon 28%, aluminum 8.3%, iron 5.6%, calcium 4.2%, sodium 2.5%, magnesium 2.4%, potassium 2.0%, and titanium 0.61%. Other elements occur at less than 0.15%.

questions.Question: The Rh factor refers to
questions.optionA: a protein substance found in the blood of some people
questions.optionB: a hormone carried by the blood
questions.optionC: the ratio of red corpuscles to white corpuscles in the blood
questions.optionD: a process that speeds up the clothing of blood
questions.solution: Solution:		The Rh factor refers to a protein substance found in the blood of some people. Rhesus (Rh) factor is an inherited protein found on the surface of red blood cells. If your blood has the protein, you're Rh positive. If your blood lacks the protein, you're Rh negative. Rh positive is the most common blood type.

questions.Question: The Reliance Cup is associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		The Reliance Cup is associated with cricket.

questions.Question: The National Emblem was adopted by Government of India on
questions.solution: Solution:		The National Emblem was adopted by Government of India on January 26, 1950. It was chosen as a symbol of contemporary India's reaffirmation of its ancient commitment to world peace and goodwill.

questions.Question: The scientist who first discovered that the earth revolves round the sun was
questions.solution: Solution:		The scientist who first discovered that the earth revolves round the sun was Copernicus. Nicolaus Copernicus was a Polish astronomer who put forth the theory that the Sun is at rest near the center of the Universe, and that the Earth, spinning on its axis once daily, revolves annually around the Sun. This is called the heliocentric, or Sun-centered, system.

questions.Question: The number of sovereign countries who are members of the United Nations, is
questions.solution: Solution:		The number of sovereign countries who are members of the United Nations, is 193. The United Nations member states are the 193 sovereign states that are members of the United Nations (UN) and have equal representation in the UN General Assembly.

questions.Question: Mount Everest was captured by Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Mount Everest was captured by Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay in the year 1953. Sherpa Tenzing Norgay stands on the summit of Everest on May 29, 1953 after he and Edmund Hillary became the first people to reach the highest point on Earth.

questions.Question: Karoline Mikkelsen was the first woman to
questions.solution: Solution:		Karoline Mikkelsen was the first woman to reach South Pole. She was a Danish-Norwegian explorer who on 20 February, 1935 was the first woman to set foot on Antarctica, although whether this was on the mainland or an island is a matter of dispute.

questions.Question: Liquids transmit pressure equally in all directions. This is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Liquids transmit pressure equally in all directions. This is known as Pascal's Law. Pascal's law says that pressure applied to an enclosed fluid will be transmitted without a change in magnitude to every point of the fluid and to the walls of the container. The pressure at any point in the fluid is equal in all directions.

questions.Question: John F. Kennedy, President of USA, died in
questions.solution: Solution:		John F. Kennedy, President of USA, died in 1963. John Fitzgerald Kennedy, the 35th President of the United States, was assassinated on November 22, 1963, at 12:30 p.m. Central Standard Time in Dallas, Texas, while riding in a presidential motorcade through Dealey Plaza.

questions.Question: Lal Bahadur Shastri
questions.optionA: succeeded Pandit Nehru as the second Prime Minister of India
questions.optionB: signed the Tashkent Agreement with Ayub Khan for a ceasefire between India and Pakistan
questions.optionC: is also known as “Man of Peace”
questions.solution: Solution:		Lal Bahadur Shastri succeeded Pandit Nehru as the second Prime Minister of India and signed the Tashkent Agreement with Ayub Khan for a ceasefire between India and Pakistan and is also known as “Man of Peace”.

questions.Question: Which Bank has the maximum number of branches?
questions.solution: Solution:		State Bank of India has the maximum number of branches. SBI becomes world's second bank to have 10,000 branches. State Bank of India on Sunday became only the second bank in the world to have 10,000 branches when Union Finance Minister P Chidambaram inaugurated its latest branch in Puduvayal district of Tamil Nadu

questions.Question: When was table tennis introduced in Olympics?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1988 at Seoul, table tennis introduced in Olympics. Table tennis is among the sports contested at the Summer Olympic Games. It was introduced at the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, where singles and doubles tournaments were held for both genders. The doubles events were dropped from the 2008 Summer Olympics program and replaced by team events.

questions.Question: Which is the associated sport of Bombay Gold Cup?
questions.solution: Solution:		Hockey is the associated sport of Bombay Gold Cup.

questions.Question: Which is the place of worship for Judoists?
questions.solution: Solution:		Synagogue is the place of worship for Judoists. A synagogue is a Jewish or Samaritan house of worship. Synagogues have a large place for prayer and may also have smaller rooms for study and sometimes a social hall and offices.

questions.Question: Which is the sacred text of Hinduism?
questions.optionC: The epics of the Mahabharata and the Ramayana
questions.solution: Solution:		The Vedas, The Bhagavad Gita and The epics of the Mahabharata and the Ramayana is the sacred text of Hinduism. The Hindu sacred texts are divided into Shruti (“What Is Heard”) and Smriti (“What Is Remembered”). The Sruti — which includes the Vedas and Upanishads — are considered to be divinely inspired while the Smriti — which includes the Mahabharata (including the Bhagavad Gita) and Ramayana — are derived from great sages.

questions.Question: Rise of the Chinese civilization along the banks of Hawang Ho took place in
questions.solution: Solution:		Rise of the Chinese civilization along the banks of Hawang Ho took place in 2205 - 1122 BC. Chinese civilization refers to that period of China's history which began in the early 2nd millennium BCE, when a literate, city-based culture first emerged, to the end of the Han dynasty, in 220 CE.

questions.Question: Presently known as the European Union, the EEC was established in
questions.solution: Solution:		Presently known as the European Union, the EEC was established in 1958. Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom join the European Union, raising the number of member states to nine. The organisation founded in 1957 which is now known as the European Union, originally had six members: Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands.

questions.Question: Steel is more elastic than Rubber because
questions.optionC: ratio of stress to strain is more
questions.optionD: ratio of stress to strain is less
questions.solution: Solution:		Steel is more elastic than Rubber because ratio of stress to strain is more. Steel is more elastic than rubber because steel comes back to its original shape faster than rubber when the deforming forces are removed.

questions.Question: The 2003 Right Livelihood Honorary Award honors ____, when the jury recognizes "for his steadfast work over many years for a world free of nuclear weapons".
questions.optionA: New Zealand's former Prime Minister David Lange
questions.solution: Solution:		The 2003 Right Livelihood Honorary Award honors New Zealand's former Prime Minister David Lange, when the jury recognizes "for his steadfast work over many years for a world free of nuclear weapons".

questions.Question: Tansen was
questions.optionA: a great exponent of Indian classical music
questions.optionB: one of the nine gems in the court of Akbar
questions.solution: Solution:		Tansen was a great exponent of Indian classical music and one of the nine gems in the court of Akbar. Tansen, the magical musician, was one of the 'Navratna' (nine gems) at the court of the Mughal Emperor Akbar. He was born in Gwalior as a son of Mukund Misra, who was a poet. As a young child he learnt music from the legendary teacher of his time, Haridas Swami.

questions.Question: The Heads of Government of the countries which are members of the Commonwealth meet
questions.solution: Solution:		The Heads of Government of the countries which are members of the Commonwealth meet biannually. The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting is a biennial summit meeting of the de facto leaders from all Commonwealth nations. Despite the name, the head of state may be present in the meeting instead of the head of government, espcially among semi-presidential states. Every two years the meeting is held in a different member state and is chaired by that nation's respective Prime Minister or President who becomes the Commonwealth Chair-in-Office until the next meeting.

questions.Question: The headquarter of the International court of Justice (UNO) are located at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of the International court of Justice (UNO) are located at Hague (Netherlands). It is the main judicial organ or branch of the United Nations. In short, International Court of Justice is ICJ, sometimes people call it the World Court. In French language, it is Cour internationale de justice. Established ICJ in 1945, ICJ has its headquarters at The Hague, Netherlands.

questions.Question: The headquarter of all the following international organization are based at Vienna, excepted
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of all the following international organization are based at Vienna, excepted United Nations Development Programme. Headquartered in New York City, the status of UNDP is that of an executive board within the United Nations General Assembly. The UNDP Administrator is the third highest-ranking official of the United Nations after the United Nations Secretary-General and Deputy Secretary-General.

questions.Question: The headquarter of European Court of Justice (ECJ) are situated at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of European Court of Justice (ECJ) are situated at Luxembourg. European Court of Justice (ECJ), also called Court of Justice of the European Communities, the judicial branch of the European Union (EU).

questions.Question: The host of first Olympics in 1896 was
questions.solution: Solution:		The host of first Olympics in 1896 was Athens, Greece. On April 6, 1896, the first modern Olympic Games are held in Athens, Greece, with athletes from 14 countries participating. The International Olympic Committee met for the first time in Paris in June 1894 and chose Greece as the site of the inaugural modern Olympiad.

questions.Question: Ms. Medha Patkar is associated with the
questions.solution: Solution:		Ms. Medha Patkar is associated with the Sardar Sarovar project. Sardar Sarovar Dam in Gujarat is one of the biggest dams on Narmada where the non-violent people's struggle has questioned social and environmental costs, undemocratic planning and unjust distribution of benefits.

questions.Question: Kathakali, Mohiniatam and Ottamthullal are the famous dances of
questions.solution: Solution:		Kathakali, Mohiniatam and Ottamthullal are the famous dances of Kerala.

questions.Question: Jaspal Rana is associated with which of the following games?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jaspal Rana is associated with Shooting. Jaspal Rana (born 28 June 1976) is an Indian shooter. He contested mainly in the 25 m Centre Fire Pistol category.

questions.Question: Lala Lajpat Rai is also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Lala Lajpat Rai is also known as Sher-e-Punjab and Punjab Kesari. He was born on 28 January 1865 in Dhudike (now Moga district) of Punjab. He was popularly known as Punjab Kesari meaning The Lion of Punjab also known as Sher-E- Punjab in Punjabi for his contribution to the freedom movement.

questions.Question: Modern football is said to have evolved from
questions.solution: Solution:		Modern football is said to have evolved from England. Football is one of a family of football codes, which emerged from various ball games played worldwide since antiquity. The modern game traces its origins to 1863 when the Laws of the Game were originally codified in England by The Football Association.

questions.Question: Which continent has maximum per capita land?
questions.solution: Solution:		Australia has maximum per capita land. It has a high - income economy, with the world's tenth highest per capita income.

questions.Question: Which of these is a modified underground stem?
questions.solution: Solution:		Potato is a modified underground stem. In potato plant slender branches develop from the underground part of the stem and grow more or less horizontally beneath the surface of the soil.

questions.Question: Who is known as the 'Lady with the Lamp'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Florence Nightingale is known as Lady with the Lamp. During the Crimean War Florence Nightingale organized a corps of nurses to care for soldiers, thus beginning her foray into the world of medical care and treatment.

questions.Question: International Youth Day is observed on -
questions.solution: Solution:		International Youth Day is observed on August 12. First observed on August 12, 2000, the day marks an awareness day and draws attention to a given set of cultural and legal issues surrounding youth.

questions.Question: Which is the highest civilian award in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bharat Ratna is the highest civilian award in India. Bharat Ratna is the highest civilian honour, given for exceptional service towards advancement of Art, Literature and Science, and in recognition of Public Service of the highest order.

questions.Question: Where is the permanent secretariat of the SAARC?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kathmandu is the permanent secretariat of the SAARC. SAARC Secretariat is based in Kathmandu, Nepal. It coordinates and monitors the implementation of activities, hosts meetings, and serves as a channel of communication between the Association and its member states as well as other regional organizations.

questions.Question: Which is the oldest paramilitary force in the country?
questions.solution: Solution:		Assam rifles is India's oldest paramilitary force, raised originally in 1835 as Cachar Levy. They perform many roles including the provision of internal security under the control of the army through the conduct of counter insurgency and border security operations. Assam Rifles is known as “Sentinels of the Northeast”.

questions.Question: When was Mahatma Gandhi assassinated?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nathuram Vinayak Godse (19 May 1910 – 15 November 1949) was the assassin of Mahatma Gandhi, who shot Gandhi in the chest three times at point blank range in New Delhi on 30 January 1948.

questions.Question: Which is the India's largest and the oldest museum?
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian Museum, Kolkata is the India's largest and the oldest museum. The Indian Museum in Kolkata, also referred to as the Imperial Museum at Calcutta in British India era texts, is the largest and oldest museum in India and has rare collections of antiques, armour and ornaments, fossils, skeletons, mummies, and Mughal paintings.

questions.Question: When was pottery developed in the Indus Valley?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pottery was developed in the Indus Valley in 3500 BC.

questions.Question: Fathometer is used to measure
questions.solution: Solution:		Fathometer is used to measure Ocean depth. Fathometer is a depth finder that uses sound waves to determine the depth of water. The Richter Scale is used to measure the intensity of Earthquakes.

questions.Question: For galvanizing iron which of the following metals is used?
questions.solution: Solution:		Zinc is used for galvanizing iron. Galvanization (or galvanizing as it is most commonly called in that industry) is the process of applying a protective zinc coating to steel or iron, to prevent rusting.

questions.Question: Economic goods are
questions.optionA: Commodities that is available according to their demand
questions.optionB: Commodities that is available more as compared to demand
questions.optionC: all commodities that are limited in quantity as compared to their demand
questions.solution: Solution:		Economic goods are all commodities that are limited in quantity as compared to their demand. An economic good is a good or service that has a benefit (utility) to society. Also, economic goods have a degree of scarcity and therefore an opportunity cost.

questions.Question: For purifying drinking water alum is used
questions.solution: Solution:		For purifying drinking water alum is used for coagulation of mud particles. Aluminium Sulfate, Shortly known as Alum, when added to raw water reacts with the bicarbonate alkalinities present in water and forms a gelatinous precipitate. The water over this sediment is almost clean other than some fine particles dissolved in it.

questions.Question: Hockey was introduced in the Asian Games in
questions.solution: Solution:		Hockey was introduced in the Asian Games in 1958 in Tokyo. Field hockey was contested for men only at the 1958 Asian Games in Tokyo, Japan between 25 May and 30 May 1958 with five teams participating in a round robin competition.

questions.Question: The main objectives of the UN are
questions.optionA: to maintain peace and security in the world
questions.optionB: to develop friendly relations among nations
questions.optionC: to work together to remove poverty, disease and illiteracy and encourage respect for each other's rights of basic freedom.
questions.solution: Solution:		The main objectives of the UN are to maintain peace and security in the world, to develop friendly relations among nations and to work together to remove poverty, disease and illiteracy and encourage respect for each other's rights of basic freedom.

questions.Question: The headquarter of ESCAP (Economic and Social Commission for Asia) are situated at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of ESCAP (Economic and Social Commission for Asia) are situated at Bangkok. Established in 1947 with its headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, UNESCAP serves as the highest intergovernmental regional platform to promote cooperation among member States for creating a more interconnected region working to achieve inclusive and sustainable economic and social development.

questions.Question: The industrial organization of Atomic Minerals Division, Heavy Water Board (HWB) is located at
questions.solution: Solution:		The industrial organization of Atomic Minerals Division, Heavy Water Board (HWB) is located at Mumbai. Heavy Water Board (HWB) is a constituent unit under the Department of Atomic Energy in the Government of India. The organisation is primarily responsible for production of Heavy Water (D2O) which is used as a 'moderator' and 'Coolant' in nuclear power as well as research reactors.

questions.Question: The Indian Air Force celebrated its Golden Jubilee in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian Air Force was officially established on 8th October 1932, and on 1st April 1954, Air Marshal Subroto Mukherjee, one of the founding members of the Air Force took over as the first Indian Chief of Air Staff.

questions.Question: The headquarter of OAU (Organization of African Unity) are at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of OAU (Organization of African Unity) are at Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Founded in 1963, it aims to safeguard the interests and independence of all African states, encourage the continent's development, and settle disputes among member states. Its headquarters are in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

questions.Question: Which is the major mineral found in Punjab?
questions.solution: Solution:		Salt is the major mineral found in Punjab. The Salt Range is a hill system in the Punjab province of Pakistan, deriving its name from its extensive deposits of rock salt. The range extends along the south of the Pothohar Plateau and the North of the Jhelum River. And in the Indian state of Punjab, Coal is the major natural resource found.

questions.Question: When was Shakespeare born?
questions.solution: Solution:		Shakespeare was born in 1564 AD. William Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England, in April 1564. The exact date of his birth is not recorded, but it is most often celebrated around the world on 23 April. Shakespeare's baptism is recorded in the Parish Register at Holy Trinity Church, Stratford-upon-Avon on Wednesday 26 April 1564.

questions.Question: Which city in Tamil Nadu has airport?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Chennai, Triuchirapalli and Madurai, Tamil Nadu has airport.

questions.Question: Which minerals are found in Chhattisgarh?
questions.solution: Solution:		Iron-ore, limestone, dolomite, coal, bauxite, corundum, gaunet, guartz, marble and diamond minerals are found in Chhattisgarh.

questions.Question: Which is post-harvest folk dance in Assam?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bihu is post-harvest folk dance in Assam. Many fairs and festivals are held in Assam. Nearly all tribal festivals are held in spring and celebrate cultivation or harvest. Among festivals in Assam, the Bihu is most noteworthy; it brings together all Assamese people, regardless of background.

questions.Question: When does the Indonesian settlement in the Malay Peninsula took place?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 2200 BC the Indonesian settlement in the Malay Peninsula took place.

questions.Question: When did US solar system probe Voyager-two discovered six new moons of the planet Uranus?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1986 US solar system probe Voyager-two discovered six new moons of the planet Uranus. Scientists believe they have discovered two new moons orbiting the planet Uranus. A team re-examining data captured by the Nasa space probe Voyager 2 in 1986 found evidence of the small, dark "moonlets" lurking behind the large gas planet and making "waves" in its closest rings.

questions.Question: What is the approximate area of Bihar?
questions.solution: Solution:		The approximate area of Bihar is 1,35,100 sq. km.

questions.Question: When did India hosted the Common wealth meeting?
questions.solution: Solution:		India hosted the Common wealth meeting in 1983 at New Delhi. The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting 1983 was the seventh Meeting of the Heads of Government of the Commonwealth of Nations. It was held in New Delhi, India, between 23 and 29 November 1983, and was hosted by that country's Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi. The retreat was held in Goa.

questions.Question: When did China exploded first atomic device?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1964 China exploded first atomic device. On October 16, 1964, China successfully tested its first atomic bomb. The uranium implosion device exploded with 22 kilotons of force atop a 330 foot steel tower.

questions.Question: The blood pressure of a young male human being is
questions.solution: Solution:		The blood pressure of a young male human being is 120/80. Normal blood pressure is considered to be anything below 120/80. Prehypertension is defined as a systolic reading between 120 and 129 and a diastolic reading lower than 80. Hypertension is defined as blood pressure of 130/80 or higher.

questions.Question: The first Winter Olympic Games were held at
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Winter Olympic Games were held at Chamonix (France). The Winter Olympic Games (French: Jeux olympiques d'hiver) is a major international multi-sport event held once every four years for sports practiced on snow and ice. The first Winter Olympic Games, the 1924 Winter Olympics, were held in Chamonix, France. The modern Olympic Games were inspired by the ancient Olympic Games, which were held in Olympia, Greece, from the 8th century BC to the 4th century AD.

questions.Question: The college of Military Engineering is situated at
questions.solution: Solution:		The college of Military Engineering is situated at Kirkee (Pune).

questions.Question: The electron was first identified by
questions.solution: Solution:		The electron was first identified by J. J. Thompson. Thomson in 1897 was the first to suggest that one of the fundamental units was more than 1,000 times smaller than an atom, suggesting the subatomic particle now known as the electron. Thomson discovered this through his explorations on the properties of cathode rays.

questions.Question: The conservation hawks and owls is important to mankind chiefly because these birds eat
questions.solution: Solution:		The conservation hawks and owls is important to mankind chiefly because these birds eat many harmful rodents.

questions.Question: Which amongst the following mammals has the highest metabolic rate in terms of oxygen consumption (mm3/g hour)?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mouse amongst the following mammals has the highest metabolic rate in terms of oxygen consumption (mm3/g hour).

questions.Question: When was Mandela inaugurated as first black President?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1994, Mandela was inaugurated as first black President. The African National Congress won 63%of the votes in the election, and Mandela, as leader of the ANC, was inaugurated on 10 May 1994 as the country's first black President, with the National Party's F.W. de Klerk as his first deputy and Thabo Mbeki as the second in the Government of National Unity.

questions.Question: Which among the sources of energy tapped in India has shown the largest growth till the Eighth plan?
questions.solution: Solution:		Thermal sources of energy tapped in India has shown the largest growth till the Eighth plan. Thermal energy (also called heat energy) is produced when a rise in temperature causes atoms and molecules to move faster and collide with each other.

questions.Question: Which body of UNO gives advisory opinion on legal matters to the bodies and special agencies of the UNO?
questions.solution: Solution:		International Court of Justice body of UNO gives advisory opinion on legal matters to the bodies and special agencies of the UNO. The International Court of Justice (ICJ), sometimes called the World Court, is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations (UN). The ICJ settles disputes between states and gives advisory opinions on international legal issues referred to it by the UN.

questions.Question: Which is the highest literary award of the world?
questions.solution: Solution:		Booker Prize is the highest literary award of the world. The leading literary award in the English speaking world, which has brought recognition, reward and readership to outstanding fiction for over 50 years. Awarded annually to the best novel of the year written in English and published in the UK or Ireland.

questions.Question: First human heart transplant operation conducted by Dr. Christian Bernard on Louis Washkansky, was conducted in
questions.solution: Solution:		Louis Washkansky (1913 - 21 December 1967) was the recipient of the world's first human heart transplant. Washkansky died of double pneumonia eighteen days after the transplant because of a weakened immune system.

questions.Question: Galileo was an Italian astronomer who
questions.optionC: discovered that the movement of pendulum produces a regular time measurement
questions.solution: Solution:		Galileo was an Italian astronomer who developed the telescope, discovered four satellites of Jupiter and discovered that the movement of pendulum produces a regular time measurement. Galileo was an Italian astronomer, mathematician, physicist, philosopher and professor who made pioneering observations of nature with long-lasting implications for the study of physics. He also constructed a telescope and supported the Copernican theory, which supports a sun-centered solar system.

questions.Question: Habeas Corpus Act 1679
questions.optionA: provided facilities to a prisoner to obtain either speedy trial or release in bail
questions.optionB: states that no one was to be imprisoned without a writ or warrant stating the charge against him
questions.optionC: safeguarded the personal liberties of the people against arbitrary imprisonment by the king's orders
questions.solution: Solution:		Habeas Corpus Act 1679 provided facilities to a prisoner to obtain either speedy trial or release in bail, states that no one was to be imprisoned without a writ or warrant stating the charge against him and safeguarded the personal liberties of the people against arbitrary imprisonment by the king's orders.

questions.Question: Exposure to sunlight helps a person improve his health because
questions.optionB: the infrared light kills bacteria in the body

questions.solution: Solution:		Exposure to sunlight helps a person improve his health because the ultraviolet rays convert skin oil into Vitamin D.

questions.Question: Golf player Vijay Singh belongs to which country?
questions.solution: Solution:		Golf player Vijay Singh belongs to Fiji. He was born in 1963, who was number 1 in the Official World Golf Ranking for 32 weeks in 2004 and 2005. He was nicknamed as "The Big Fijian", has won three major Golf Championships.

questions.Question: The official languages of the United Nations are
questions.optionA: African, Chinese, English, French, German and Spanish

questions.solution: Solution:		The six official languages of the United Nations are:1. Arabic 2. Chinese (Mandarin) 3. English 4. French 5. Russian 6. Spanish

questions.Question: The news agency Reuters belongs to which of the following country?
questions.solution: Solution:		The news agency Reuters belongs to Yugoslavia. Yugoslavia was a country in Southeastern and Central Europe for most of the 20th century.

questions.Question: The sacred place of the followers of Shintoism is
questions.optionA: Central shrine of Ise (Central of Japan)
questions.solution: Solution:		The sacred place of the followers of Shintoism is Central shrine of Ise (Central of Japan) and Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo. A shrine (jinja) is a sacred place where kami live, and which show the power and nature of the kami.

questions.Question: The smallest state of India is
questions.solution: Solution:		Goa with an area of 3702 sq. km is the smallest State in India.

questions.Question: The parts of the Mahabharata which include Bhagawad Gita, is
questions.solution: Solution:		The parts of the Mahabharata which include Bhagawad Gita, is more than 2500 years old. Kurukshetra is a city in the Indian state of Haryana. It is also known as Dharmakshetra ("Holy Place") and as the "Land of the Bhagavad Gita".

questions.Question: The chemical name of Vitamin B is
questions.solution: Solution:		The chemical name of Vitamin B is thiamine. Thiamine, also known as thiamin or vitamin B1, is a vitamin found in food, and manufactured as a dietary supplement and medication. Food sources of thiamine include whole grains, legumes, and some meats and fish.

questions.Question: The first Indian actress to have been nominated to the Rajya Sabha was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Indian actress to have been nominated to the Rajya Sabha was Nargis Dutt. Nargis was the first actor to be honored with the Padmashree Award; she was also nominated to the Rajya Sabha (Indian Parliament) for her charitable work for spastics. Won the National Award for her role in Raat Aur Din (1967). Half-sister of Anwar Hussain and Akhtar Hussain.

questions.Question: The first NAM (Non-Aligned Movement) conference was held at
questions.solution: Solution:		The first NAM (Non-Aligned Movement) conference was held at Belgrade (Yugoslavia). The Non-Aligned Movement was founded and held its first conference (the Belgrade Conference) in 1961 under the leadership of Josip Broz Tito of Yugoslavia, Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt, Jawaharlal Nehru of India, Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana, and Sukarno of Indonesia.

questions.Question: The first recipient of Bharat Ratna award in 1954 was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first recipient of Bharat Ratna award in 1954 was C. Rajagopalachari. Chakravarti Rajagopalachari (C. Rajagopalachari; 10 December 1878 – 25 December 1972), informally called Rajaji or C.R., was an Indian politician, independence activist, lawyer, writer, historian and statesman. Rajagopalachari was the last Governor-General of India, as India soon became a Republic in 1950. Furthermore, he was the first Indian-born governor-general, since before him the posts were held by British nationals.

questions.Question: The credit of developing the polio vaccine goes to
questions.solution: Solution:		The credit of developing the polio vaccine goes to Jones Salk. Jonas Edward Salk was an American medical researcher and virologist. He discovered and developed one of the first successful polio vaccines.

questions.Question: Rare Earth factory is situated in
questions.solution: Solution:		Rare Earth factory is situated in Alwaye (Kerala). Rare Earths Division (RED), Udyogamandal, Aluva is located on the banks of river Periyar in Kerala at a distance of 12 km from the Port city of Kochi and 15 km from Kochi International Airport. RED is an exclusive value adding chemical plant, wherein high pure individual rare earth compounds are produced.

questions.Question: Pakistan left the Commonwealth in 1972, but rejoined as 49th member of the Commonwealth in
questions.solution: Solution:		Pakistan left the Commonwealth in 1972, but rejoined as 49th member of the Commonwealth in 1989. Pakistan left in 1972, when other member countries recognised Bangladesh, and returned in 1989.

questions.Question: Primary rainbow is formed when light suffers
questions.optionA: two internal refractions before emerging out of the drop
questions.optionB: one internal refractions before emerging out of the drop
questions.optionD: either one or two internal refractions before emerging out of the drop
questions.solution: Solution:		Primary rainbow is formed when light suffers one internal refractions before emerging out of the drop. In a primary rainbow, the arc shows red on the outer part and violet on the inner side. This rainbow is caused by light being refracted when entering a droplet of water, then reflected inside on the back of the droplet and refracted again when leaving it.

questions.Question: Rana Pratap Sagar (Rajasthan) is famous for
questions.solution: Solution:		Rana Pratap Sagar (Rajasthan) is famous for nuclear power station. The Rana Pratap Sagar Dam facilitates fishing activities in the nearby villages and is also responsible for supplying water to the Rajasthan Atomic Power Station for generation of electricity.

questions.Question: The chief constituent of gobar gas is
questions.solution: Solution:		The chief constituent of gobar gas is methane. Biogas comprises primarily methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) and may have small amounts of hydrogen sulphide (H2S), moisture and siloxanes.

questions.Question: In a normal human body, the total number of red blood cells is
questions.solution: Solution:		In a normal human body, the total number of red blood cells is 30 trillion. Women have roughly 4 to 5 million red blood cells per microliter of blood, whereas men have about 5 to 6 million per microliter of blood. Red blood cells comprise approximately 70% of total human body cell number.

questions.Question: INS Venduruthy is located at
questions.solution: Solution:		INS Venduruthy is an Indian Navy base located on Willingdon Island in Kochi, Kerala. It serves as the Headquarters of the Southern Naval Command.

questions.Question: In which season do we need more fat?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Winter season we need more fat. Researchers suggest that we have a natural tendency to overeat in the winter because, historically, food was more scarce.

questions.Question: How much districts are there in Punjab?
questions.solution: Solution:		There are 22 districts in Punjab. The districts listed are: Amritsar, Bathinda, Faridkot, Firozpur, Fatehgarh Sahib, Kapurthala, Gurdaspur, Hoshiarpur, Jalandhar, Ludhiana, Mansa, Moga, Muktsar, Nawanshahr, Patiala, Rupnagar, Sangrur, and Tarn Taran.

questions.Question: India participated in Olympics Hockey in
questions.solution: Solution:		India participated in Olympics Hockey in 1928. The 1928 Olympics in Amsterdam, when India won the gold, was the country's first step towards ascending the hockey throne.

questions.Question: The largest cantilever bridge of India is
questions.solution: Solution:		Howrah Bridge on the Hoogly river, Calcutta is the largest cantilever bridge in India. The Howrah Bridge, which connects the twin cities of Kolkata and Howrah.

questions.Question: The headquarter of United Nations Fund for Programmes Population Activities (UNFA) are at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of United Nations Fund for Programmes Population Activities (UNFA) are at New York. The UNFPA says it "is the lead UN agency for delivering a world where every pregnancy is wanted, every childbirth is safe and every young person's potential is fulfilled". Their work involves the improvement of reproductive health; including creation of national strategies and protocols, and birth control by providing supplies and services. The organization has recently been known for its worldwide campaign against child marriage, obstetric fistula and female genital mutilation.

questions.Question: The Himalayan Mountaineering Institute is located in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Himalayan Mountaineering Institute is located in Darjeeling. The Himalayan Mountaineering Institute (HMI) is one of the premier mountaineering institutes in the world. Founded on November 4th, 1954 by none other than Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, the first Prime Minister of India, the institute is located in the picturesque hill station of Darjeeling.

questions.Question: Deforestation in the uplands may cause pollution in rivers through
questions.solution: Solution:		Deforestation in the uplands may cause pollution in rivers through erosion and silting. Deforestation is the permanent removal of trees to make room for something besides forest. This can include clearing the land for agriculture or grazing, or using the timber for fuel, construction or manufacturing. Forests cover more than 30% of the Earth's land surface, according to the World Wildlife Fund.

questions.Question: The Indian Ocean Arc is an imaginary circle in space about ____ over the equator
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian Ocean Arc is an imaginary circle in space about 36,000 km over the equator. IOR-ARC is Indian Ocean Rim Association for Regional Cooperation (IOR-ARC) is an association of 20 member countries.

questions.Question: The SAF (South Asian Federation) Game, as a part of the SAARC programme, was first held in
questions.solution: Solution:		The SAF (South Asian Federation) Game, as a part of the SAARC programme, was first held in 1984. From 1984 to 1987 they were held every year except 1986, as it was a year of Commonwealth Games and Asian Games. From 1987 onwards, they have been held every two years except for some occasions.

questions.Question: The normal threshold of hearing is around
questions.solution: Solution:		The normal threshold of hearing is around 25-45 db.

questions.Question: The refrigerant commonly used for domestic refrigerators is
questions.solution: Solution:		The refrigerant commonly used for domestic refrigerators is ammonia. Ammonia, frequently used commercially in large freezing and refrigeration plants is also called “anhydrous ammonia” because it contains almost no water (it is 99.98% pure).

questions.Question: The normal term of office for which the President and Vice-President of the International Court of Justice are elected is
questions.solution: Solution:		The normal term of office for which the President and Vice-President of the International Court of Justice are elected is three years.

questions.Question: The ozone layer is being destroyed by chlorofluorocarbons. In this regard which do you consider as the most harmful?
questions.solution: Solution:		The ozone layer is being destroyed by chlorofluorocarbons. In this regard Fluorine atom is considered as the most harmful. Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) could deplete Earth's atmospheric ozone layer, which blocks the sun's damaging ultraviolet rays. When the scientists reported their findings in 1974, CFCs were widely used as refrigerant gases and as propellants in aerosol sprays.

questions.Question: The exhaled air contains
questions.optionB: a mixture of carbon dioxide and nitrogen
questions.optionC: a mixture which has more carbon dioxide than oxygen

questions.solution: Solution:		The exhaled air contains a mixture of carbon dioxide, nitrogen and oxygen in which nitrogen has the highest percentage. Exhaled air contains less oxygen and more carbon dioxide, it is also saturated with water vapour. Exhaled air contains: 78% nitrogen and16% oxygen.

questions.Question: The full-fledged Commonwealth Games were first organized in ____ at ____
questions.solution: Solution:		The full-fledged Commonwealth Games were first organized in 1930 at Hamilton in Canada. The Commonwealth Games is an international multi-sport event involving athletes from the Commonwealth of Nations. The event was first held in 1930, and has taken place every four years since then.

questions.Question: Wright Brothers are regarded inventors of the
questions.solution: Solution:		Wright Brothers are regarded inventors of the Aeroplane. The Wright brothers Orville (August 19, 1871 – January 30, 1948) and Wilbur (April 16, 1867 – May 30, 1912) – were two American aviation pioneers generally credited with inventing, building, and flying the world's first successful airplane.

questions.Question: World War II was fought between
questions.optionA: Axis Power (Germany, Italy and Japan) against the Allies (Britain, USSR, USA, France)
questions.optionB: Austria, Hungary, Turkey against France, USA, Japan
questions.solution: Solution:		World War II was fought between Axis Power (Germany, Italy and Japan) against the Allies (Britain, USSR, USA, France). World War II (often abbreviated to WWII or WW2), also known as the Second World War, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945. The vast majority of the world's countries including all the great powers eventually formed two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis.

questions.Question: The basic cause of World War II was
questions.optionB: rise of the Nazi Party in Germany
questions.optionC: Japan's policy of expansion and imperialism of England and France

questions.Question: The main reserves of phosphorus in the biosphere is in the
questions.solution: Solution:		The main reserves of phosphorus in the biosphere is in the lithosphere. Unlike many other biogeochemical cycles, the atmosphere does not play a significant role in the movement of phosphorus, because phosphorus and phosphorus-based compounds are usually solids at the typical ranges of temperature and pressure found on Earth.

questions.Question: Frederick Sanger is a twice recipient of the Nobel Prize for

questions.Question: UNO Day is on

questions.Question: The influx of domestic sewage containing detergents cause nutrient enrichment in water bodies due to the presence of
questions.solution: Solution:		The influx of domestic sewage containing detergents cause nutrient enrichment in water bodies due to the presence of phosphates. The presence of phosphates in a body of water indicates its pollution with sewage or other organic wastes. questions.Question: Who amongst the following had called Rabindranath Tagore as THE GREAT SENTINEL?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahatma Gandhi amongst the following had called Rabindranath Tagore as THE GREAT SENTINEL. Rabindranath Tagore was a key figure of the Bengal Renaissance. He started writing at an early age and by the turn of the century had become a household name in Bengal as a poet, a songwriter, a playwright, an essayist, a short story writer and a novelist. In 1913 he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature and his verse collection Gitanjali came to be known internationally. At about the same time he founded Visva-Bharati, a university located in Santiniketan, near Kolkata. Called the ‘Great Sentinel’ of modern India by Mahatma Gandhi, Tagore steered clear of active politics but is famous for returning his knighthood as a gesture of protest against the Jallianwala Bagh massacre in 1919.

questions.Question: Garampani sanctuary is located at
