questions.Question: The first development flight of SLV-3 took place on
questions.solution: Solution:		The first development flight of SLV-3 took place on May 31, 1981. The first successful launch took place on 18 July, 1980. It was a four-stage rocket with all solid-propellant motors. The first launch of the SLV took place in Sriharikota on 10 August 1979.

questions.Question: The Enron project is a
questions.solution: Solution:		The Enron project is a gas-fired power project. The Dabhol Power Company (now called RGPPL - Ratnagiri Gas and Power Private Limited) was a company based in Maharashtra, India, formed in 1992 to manage and operate the controversial Dabhol Power Plant. The Dabhol plant was built through the combined effort of Enron as the majority share holder, and GE, and Bechtel as minority share holders.

questions.Question: The chief purpose of crop rotation is to check the loss of top soil
questions.solution: Solution:		The chief purpose of crop rotation is to check the loss of top soil of its mineral content. By crop rotation soil is able to get its lost nitrogen content and other minerals. It helps to check the minerals in the soil. And also it improves the soil fertility.

questions.Question: World's busiest airports by passenger traffic is
questions.optionC: King Abdul Aziz International Airport, Saudi Arabia
questions.optionD: Chicago O' Hare International Airport, USA
questions.solution: Solution:		World's busiest airports by passenger traffic is Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, USA. The Atlanta, Georgia, airport is the busiest passenger airport in the world, handling more than 107 million passengers in 2018, according to Airports Council International.

questions.Question: The first Olympics in the city of Olympia in Greece took place in
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Olympics in the city of Olympia in Greece took place in 776 BC. They continued to be celebrated when Greece came under Roman rule, until the emperor Theodosius I suppressed them in AD 393 as part of the campaign to impose Christianity as the State religion of Rome. The games were held every four years, or olympiad, which became a unit of time in historical chronologies.

questions.Question: The clear sky looks blue because
questions.solution: Solution:		The clear sky looks blue because of dispersion of light. A clear cloudless day-time sky is blue because molecules in the air scatter blue light from the sun more than they scatter red light. When we look towards the sun at sunset, we see red and orange colours because the blue light has been scattered out and away from the line of sight.

questions.Question: The common terms used in shooting are
questions.optionC: bou, bucket, low, feather, paddle, regatta
questions.solution: Solution:		The common terms used in shooting are bed, ballsege, marksmanship, plug.

questions.Question: The buoyancy depends on
questions.optionC: the mass of the liquid displaced
questions.optionD: the depth to which the body is immersed
questions.solution: Solution:		The buoyancy depends on the mass of the liquid displaced. According to Archimedes principle, the buoyant force of a partially immersed body is equal to the weight of the displaced liquid. Therefore the buoyant force depends upon the density of the fluid and the submerged volume of the body.

questions.Question: The first chairman of the Africa fund committee was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first chairman of the Africa fund committee was Late Rajiv Gandhi.

questions.Question: The Indian Olympic Council was established in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian Olympic Council was established in 1924. In 1923-24, a provisional All India Olympic Committee was set-up, which organised the All India Olympic Games (that later became the National Games of India) in February 1924.

questions.Question: The last Hindu king whose party succeeded in establishing "Hindu Swaraj" was
questions.solution: Solution:		The last Hindu king whose party succeeded in establishing "Hindu Swaraj" was Chhatrapati Shivaji. Chhatrapati Shivaji was one of the bravest, most progressive and sensible rulers of India. The founder of the Maratha Kingdom, Shivaji was born to be a natural leader and fighter on 19th February, 1630 in the prestigious Shivneri Fort. Till date, the day is celebrated as Shiv Jayanti with great rigour and traditional style by Maharashtrians.

questions.Question: The king of Macedonia, who conquered most of Asia Minor and defeated Porus (India) in 327 B. C. was
questions.solution: Solution:		The king of Macedonia, who conquered most of Asia Minor and defeated Porus (India) in 327 B. C. was Alexander the Great. Alexander enters India In 326 B.C., Alexander met King Porus of Paurava at the Hydaspes River. Porus's army was less experienced than Alexander's, but they had a secret weapon elephants. Even so, after a fierce battle in a raging thunderstorm, Porus was defeated.

questions.Question: The largest lake in India is
questions.solution: Solution:		The largest lake in India is Wular lake. Wular Lake, located in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, is often referred to as the largest freshwater lake in India. Wular is a natural lake that is a major part of the Jhelum River basin.

questions.Question: The headquarter of the International Committee of Red Cross are at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of the International Committee of Red Cross are at Geneva. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is a humanitarian institution based in Geneva, Switzerland, and a three-time Nobel Prize Laureate.

questions.Question: How many medals came into the account of India during the 2002 Commonwealth Games at Manchester?
questions.solution: Solution:		69 medals came into the account of India during the 2002 Commonwealth Games at Manchester. India won unprecedented 69 medals including 30 gold, 22 silver and 17 bronze and were fourth in the medal tally.

questions.Question: If the plane of the earth's equator were not inclined to the plane of the earth's orbit
questions.optionD: there would be no change of seasons
questions.solution: Solution:		If the plane of the earth's equator were not inclined to the plane of the earth's orbit there would be no change of seasons. When tilted, the hemisphere closer to the sun would experience summer, while the hemisphere that is relatively farther away would experience winter. If the earth were not tilted, the whole planet would be relatively equidistant from the sun, and hence, no seasons.

questions.Question: India played its first cricket Test Match in
questions.solution: Solution:		India played its first cricket Test Match in 1932. India was invited to The Imperial Cricket Council in 1926, and made their debut as a Test playing nation in England in 1932, led by CK Nayudu, who was considered as the best Indian batsman at the time. The one-off Test match between the two sides was played at Lord's in London.

questions.Question: India has been represented as a non-permanent member of the Security Council (UNO) during
questions.solution: Solution:		India has been represented as a non-permanent member of the Security Council (UNO) during 1972-73, 1984-85 and 1991-92.

questions.Question: How many Lok Sabha seats does Goa have?
questions.solution: Solution:		Goa have two Lok Sabha seats. South Goa Lok Sabha constituency (formerly, Mormugao Lok Sabha constituency) is one of two Lok Sabha (parliamentary) constituencies in Goa in western India along with North Goa.

questions.Question: Shaurya Chakra made up of bronze is awarded for
questions.optionA: gallantry in the presence of enemy
questions.optionB: gallantry otherwise than in the face of the enemy
questions.optionC: most conspicuous bravery for some act of self sacrifice
questions.solution: Solution:		Shaurya Chakra made up of bronze is awarded for gallantry otherwise than in the face of the enemy. The Shaurya Chakra is an Indian military decoration awarded for valour, courageous action or self-sacrifice while not engaged in direct action with the enemy. It may be awarded to civilians as well as military personnel, sometimes posthumously.

questions.Question: Sushri Lata Dinanath Mangeshkar received Bharath Ratna in
questions.solution: Solution:		Sushri Lata Dinanath Mangeshkar received Bharath Ratna in 2001. She is one of the best-known and most respected playback singers in India. She has recorded songs in over a thousand Hindi films and has sung songs in over thirty-six regional Indian languages and foreign languages, though primarily in Marathi, Hindi, and Bengali.

questions.Question: Taoism is followed in
questions.optionC: China, Taiwan, Nauru, Brunei, Singapore and Vietnam
questions.solution: Solution:		Taoism is a Chinese philosophy attributed to Lao Tzu which contributed to the folk religion of the people primarily in the rural areas of China and became the official religion of the country under the Tang Dynasty. Taoism is therefore both a philosophy and a religion. Taoism is also known as Daoism.

questions.Question: The 2005 Wimbledon Women's Singles champion defeated which of the following to win the title?
questions.solution: Solution:		The 2005 Wimbledon Women's Singles champion defeated Lindsay Davenport to win the title. It was the longest Wimbledon women's final match in history, lasting two hours and 45 minutes.

questions.Question: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman is a well known freedom fighter of
questions.solution: Solution:		Sheikh Mujibur Rahman is a well known freedom fighter of Bangladesh. He is often called the father of Bengali nation. He served as the first President of Bangladesh and later as the Prime Minister of Bangladesh from 17 April 1971 until his assassination on 15 August 1975. He is considered to be the driving force behind the independence of Bangladesh. He is popularly dubbed with the title of "Bangabandhu" (Bôngobondhu "Friend of Bengal") by the people of Bangladesh. He became a leading figure in and eventually the leader of the Awami League, founded in 1949 as an East Pakistan-based political party in Pakistan.

questions.Question: Yelena Isinbayeva is associated with which of the following games/sports?
questions.solution: Solution:		Yelena Isinbayeva is associated with Pole vault. Yelena Gadzhievna Isinbayeva (born 3 June 1982) is a Russian former pole vaulter. She is a two-time Olympic gold medalist (2004 and 2008), a three-time World Champion (2005, 2007 and 2013), the current world record holder in the event, and is widely considered the greatest female pole-vaulter of all time.

questions.Question: Why the Indus valley culture called Harappan culture?
questions.optionA: The first discovery comes from Harappa
questions.optionB: It was first discovery by a person called Harappa
questions.optionC: Harappa is the biggest site discovered so far
questions.optionD: Most of the valuable remains have come from Harappa
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indus valley culture is called Harappan culture because the first discovery comes from Harappa. The Harappan civilization takes its name from Harappa, the archeological site where the first evidence of a new Bronze Age urban culture was unearthed. The term Harappa is simply the Urdu name for the location.

questions.Question: When did India enter into space age by launching the satellite 'Aryabhatta'?
questions.solution: Solution:		India enter into space age in 1975 by launching the satellite 'Aryabhatta'. It was launched by India on 19 April 1975 from Kapustin Yar, a Russian rocket launch and development site in Astrakhan Oblast using a Kosmos-3M launch vehicle.

questions.Question: Recently lead free petrol was introduced in our country because
questions.optionA: they are not needed now as anti-knock agents
questions.optionC: they tower the efficiency of the engine
questions.optionD: to reduce the cost of petrol
questions.solution: Solution:		Recently lead free petrol was introduced in our country because they cause less pollution. Worldwide studies have revealed that leaded petrol is responsible for 90 per cent of all airborne lead pollution. In India, petrol with a low lead content (0.15 gm/l instead of 0.56 gm/l) was introduced in the four metros in 1994.

questions.Question: Rabindranath Tagore receive Nobel Prize in 1913 in the field of
questions.solution: Solution:		Rabindranath Tagore receive Nobel Prize in 1913 in the field of literature. questions.Question: People who secretly indulge in anti-national or anti-government activities and help the enemy are called
questions.solution: Solution:		People who secretly indulge in anti-national or anti-government activities and help the enemy are called Fifth column. A fifth column is any group of people who undermine a larger group from within, usually in favor of an enemy group or nation. The activities of a fifth column can be overt or clandestine. Fifth column Refers to traitors or people who secretly indulge in anti-national or anti -government activities and help the enemy.

questions.Question: Sulphur is not present in
questions.solution: Solution:		Sulphur is not present in chlorapatite. Chlorapatite is formed in fluor-deficient environments, and found in calcium silicate marbles, in layered mafic intrusions and in diabases. It is known to replace triphylite in some granite pegmatites (Ptáček 2016). A monoclinic polymorph, chlorapatite-M is known.

questions.Question: Oxygen was independently discovered by
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxygen was independently discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele, in Uppsala, in 1773 or earlier, and Joseph Priestley in Wiltshire, in 1774, but Priestley is often given priority because his work was published first.

questions.Question: Gabriel Daniel Fahrenheit was
questions.solution: Solution:		Gabriel Daniel Fahrenheit was a German Physicist, devised temperature scale and developed the mercury thermometer in 1714. He invented the alcohol thermometer (1709), the first mercury thermometer (1714) and devised the Fahrenheit temperature scale. He also showed the boiling points of liquids vary with changes in pressure and that water can remain liquid below its freezing point.

questions.Question: During the first crusade, crusaders reached Jerusalem and captured it in
questions.solution: Solution:		During the first crusade, crusaders reached Jerusalem and captured it in 1099 AD. questions.Question: In which year, terrorists crash two planes into New York's World Trade Centre on September 11 in a sequence of destruction?
questions.solution: Solution:		In year 2001, terrorists crash two planes into New York's World Trade Centre on September 11 in a sequence of destruction. questions.Question: In which of the following years, the membership of the Security Council was increased from 11 to 15 (under Article 23)?

questions.Question: Guarantee to an exporter that the importer of his goods will pay immediately for the goods ordered by him, is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Guarantee to an exporter that the importer of his goods will pay immediately for the goods ordered by him, is known as Letter of Credit (L/C). A Letter of Credit, also known as LC or Documentary Credit, is a commonly used instrument for effecting payment between a buyer and a seller. It can be a vital part of mitigating a seller's risk of payment in either international trade or domestic business.

questions.Question: First Afghan War took place in
questions.solution: Solution:		First Afghan War took place in 1839. The First Anglo-Afghan War (also known by the British as the Disaster in Afghanistan) was fought between the British East India Company and the Emirate of Afghanistan from 1839 to 1842.

questions.Question: Gulf cooperation council was originally formed by
questions.optionA: Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and United Arab Emirates
questions.solution: Solution:		Gulf cooperation council was created on May 25, 1981, the 630-million-acre (2,500,000 km2) Council comprises the Persian Gulf states of Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. The unified economic agreement between the countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council was signed on November 11, 1981 in Abu Dhabi. These countries are often referred to as The GCC States.

questions.Question: First China War was fought between
questions.solution: Solution:		First China War was fought between China and Britain. It was fought from 1839 - 42. It is also known as first Opium war.

questions.Question: Dumping is

questions.optionB: the process by which the supply of a manufacture's product remains low in the domestic market, which
questions.solution: Solution:		Dumping is a term that is used in financial markets as well as in international trade. In the context of buying and selling securities, dumping refers to the practice of selling large blocks of securities. More specifically, when dumping securities the seller is primarily interested in getting rid of the securities at any price. One simply dumps, or unloads, on the market with no regard to the selling price of the securities.

questions.Question: What is Bhakti movement?

questions.Question: When and where athletics introduced in the Olympics?
questions.solution: Solution:		Athletics was introduced in the Olympics in 1896 at Athens. On April 6, 1896, the first modern Olympic Games are held in Athens, Greece, with athletes from 14 countries participating. The International Olympic Committee met for the first time in Paris in June 1894 and chose Greece as the site of the inaugural modern Olympiad.

questions.Question: What was the purpose of establishment of NATO?

questions.optionC: TO provide collective defence and economic cooperation in south-east Asia
questions.solution: Solution:		The purpose of establishment of NATO was to maintain and develop individual and collective capacity to resist armed attack. NATO was the first peacetime military alliance the United States entered into outside of the Western Hemisphere.

questions.Question: Mudumalai Sanctuary is situated in:
questions.solution: Solution:		Mudumalai Sanctuary is situated in Tamil Nadu. The Mudumalai National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary also a declared tiger reserve, lies on the northwestern side of the Nilgiri Hills (Blue Mountains), in Nilgiri District, about 150 kilometres (93 mi) north-west of Coimbatore city in Tamil Nadu. It shares its boundaries with the states of Karnataka and Kerala.

questions.Question: What is the role of WTO (World Trade Organisation)?
questions.optionA: To settle trade disputes between nations
questions.optionB: To widen the principal of free trade to sectors such as services and agriculture
questions.solution: Solution:		The role of WTO (World Trade Organisation) was to settle trade disputes between nations and to widen the principal of free trade to sectors such as services and agriculture. questions.Question: When did Christopher Columbus discovered the West Indies?
questions.solution: Solution:		Christopher Columbus discovered the West Indies in 1492 AD. He was an Italian explorer and colonizer who completed four voyages across the Atlantic Ocean that opened the New World for conquest and permanent European colonization of the Americas.

questions.Question: When did the USSR formally disintegrates into 15 republics?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1991 the USSR formally disintegrates into 15 republics. In the decades after it was established, the Russian-dominated Soviet Union grew into one of the world’s most powerful and influential states and eventually encompassed 15 republics–Russia, Ukraine, Georgia, Belorussia, Uzbekistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia. In 1991, the Soviet Union was dissolved following the collapse of its communist government.

questions.Question: What was the purpose of EFTA (European Free Trade Association)?

questions.Question: Indian Institute of Petroleum is located at

questions.Question: In which year during World War I, USA declared war on Germany, Britain defeated Turkey and captured Baghdad and Jerusalem?

questions.solution: Solution:		In 1947, Algeria became politically unified with France but the 80 percent population revolted against French domination Muslim.

questions.Question: The headquarter of Army is situated at

questions.Question: The headquarter of the International Court of Justice is at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of the International Court of Justice is at The Hague. The International Court of Justice (French La Cour internationale de justice (CIJ), is an international organization. It is the main judicial organ or branch of the United Nations. In short, International Court of Justice is ICJ; sometimes people call it the World Court. In French language, it is Cour internationale de justice. Established ICJ in 1945, ICJ has its headquarters at The Hague, Netherlands. The ICJ began its working from 1946. It replaced an earlier similar court named Permanent Court of International Justice.

questions.Question: The highest rank in Army is that of
questions.solution: Solution:		The highest rank in Army is that of General. The highest rank attainable in the Army is the five-star General of the Army. Often called a "five-star general", the rank of General of the Army has historically been reserved for wartime use and is not currently active in the U.S. Army.

questions.Question: The headquarter of Asian Development Bank is located in which of the following cities
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarter of Asian Development Bank is located in Manila. questions.Question: The Melghat Tiger reserve is in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Melghat Tiger reserve is in Maharashtra. Melghat was declared a tiger reserve and was among the first nine tiger reserves notified in 1973-74 under the Project Tiger. It is located at 21°26′45″N 77°11′50″E in northern part of Amravati District of Maharashtra State in India.

questions.Question: Richter scale is used for measuring
questions.solution: Solution:		Richter scale is used for measuring intensity of earthquakes. The Richter scale measures the maximum amplitude of seismic waves as they reach seismographs. This scale is expressed with a logarithmic scale. Thus, an earthquake measuring 7.0 on the Richter scale would be 10 times larger than an earthquake that measures 6.0.

questions.Question: Prince Charles and Princess Diana of Britain announce their separation in
questions.solution: Solution:		Prince Charles and Princess Diana of Britain announce their separation in 1996. In July 1996, the couple agreed on the terms of their divorce.

questions.Question: Paleontology is a branch of science that deals with the
questions.optionD: forms of life as revealed by fossils of animals or plants
questions.solution: Solution:		Paleontology is a branch of science that deals with the forms of life as revealed by fossils of animals or plants. Paleontology is the study of the history of life on Earth as based on fossils. Fossils are the remains of plants, animals, fungi, bacteria, and single-celled living things that have been replaced by rock material or impressions of organisms preserved in rock.

questions.Question: Sir Humphry Davy was a British chemist who
questions.optionA: invented the safety lamp for miners
questions.optionB: discovered the anesthetic properties of nitrous oxide
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Humphry Davy was a British chemist who invented the safety lamp for miners and discovered the anesthetic properties of nitrous oxide. questions.Question: Sonia Nazario of "Los Angeles Times" was awarded Pulitzer Prize in 2003 for
questions.solution: Solution:		Sonia Nazario of "Los Angeles Times" was awarded Pulitzer Prize in 2003 for feature writing. The story was awarded the 2003 Pulitzer Prize for feature writing and later became a book.

questions.Question: Ecology deals with

questions.solution: Solution:		Ecology deals with relation between organisms and their environment. Ecology is the study of the interaction of organisms in an area with their environment. However, the availability of organisms in an area is dependent on the type of environment.

questions.Question: Who was the first Indian Chief of Army Staff of the Indian Army ?

questions.Question: The treaty which ushered in NATO, was signed by the member nations at

questions.Question: Numismatics is the study of
questions.solution: Solution:		Numismatics is the study of coins. Numismatics is the study of coins and money, of coins and coin-like objects. The value of coins as historical evidence was understood even in antiquity, but the systematic development of the study of coins as a proper discipline, with a methodology of its own, began only in the late eighteenth century with the work of Joseph Hilarius Eckhel, an Austrian priest whose Doctrina Numorum Veterum (Vienna, 1793-1799) was an attempt to comprehend all of ancient Greek and Roman coinage in the span of eight volumes.

questions.Question: The term used to describe many that flows into a country to take advantage of high rates of interest is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The term used to describe many that flows into a country to take advantage of high rates of interest is called hot money.
